Description: THESE FUNDS WILL HELP THE GRANTEE ACT AS A TECHNICAL EXPERT FOR THE BENEFIT OF THE NAVAJO NATION ON MINE SITES ON ABANDONED URANIUM MINE SITES THAT POSE A PUBLIC HEALTH EMERGENCY FOR THE NAVAJO PEOPLE. THE GRANTEE WILL HELP PROVIDE INFORMATION TO REQUESTERS SUCH AS EPA, PRINCIPLE RESPONSIBLE PARTIES, FEDERAL AGENCIES, AND ASSIST WITH SITE INVESTIGATION AND RESPONSE ACTIVITY. THE GRANTEE IS EXPECTED TO PARTICIPATE IN THE TEN-YEAR-PLAN COORDINATION AND REPORTING.  THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT PROVIDES PARTIAL FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $415,000.

FUNDING IS PROVIDED TO THE GRANTEE FOR SITE DISCOVERY AND PRE-REMEDIAL SITE SCREENING OF SITES WHERE A RELASE OF HAZARDOUS SUBSTANCES MAY HAVE OCCURRED, TO DETERMINE SITE ELIGIBILITY FOR THE NATIONAL PRIORITIES LIST OR OTHER CLEANUP PROGRAM.  THIS AGREEMENT PROVIDES FULL FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $500,000.

THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT'S PROJECT OBJECTIVE IS TO SUPPORT NEVADA DIVISION OF ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION (NDEP) BY PROVIDING FUNDING FOR ITS PRELIMINARY ASSESSMENT AND SITE INSPECTION (PA/SI) ACTIVITIES, INCLUDING ASSESSING AND PRIORITIZING ABANDONED MINE LANDS (AML) SITES FOR POTENTIAL CLEAN-UP.  THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT PROVIDES FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $175,000.

THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT PROVIDES FEDERAL FUNDING FOR PRELIMINARY ASSESSMENT/SITE INSPECTION (PA/SI) WORK, INCLUDING  SITE DISCOVERY AND SITE SCREENING ACTIVITIES.  THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT PROVIDES FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF  $275,000.

THIS IS A COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT WILL BENEFIT AND SUPPORT THE GRANTEE BY PROVIDING FUNDING FOR STATE INVOLVEMENT ON NATIONAL PRIORITY LIST (NPL) SITES. SPECIFIC TASKS TO BE CARRIED OUT ARE:  REVIEW AND PROVIDE INPUT ON EPA EVALUATIONS, TECHNICAL ANALYSIS, AND REMEDIAL DECISIONS INCLUDING REMEDIAL INVESTIGATION /FEASIBILITY STUDY (RI/FS) WORK, RISK ASSESSMENTS AND COODINATION WITH REGULATORY AGENCIES AND FACIILITY OWNERS/OPERATERS FOR STATE SUPERFUND CONTRACT (SSC) NEGOTIATIONS AND REVIEW OF SSC INVOICES.  THIS AGREEMENT PROVIDES FULL FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $280,000.

THE NAVAJO NATION AIR QUALITY CONTROL PROGRAM WILL ASSIST WITH THE COVE AIR STUDY. SPECIFICALLY, NAVAJO NATION WILL COORDINATE WITH THE COMMUNITY TO ENSURE AIR MONITORS ARE CHECKED FIVE DAYS/WEEK, PURCHASE AND SET UP A METEOROLOGICAL STATION AT THE COVE COMMUNITY CENTER, AND COLLECT WEEKLY SAMPLES FROM MONITORS AT FIVE LOCATIONS IN COVE, ARIZONA FOR THE YEARLONG SAMPLING EVENT.  THIS AGREEMENT PROVIDES FULL FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $89,260.

THIS PROJECT PROVIDES FOR FEDERAL/STATE COORDINATION AND THE STATE'S ACTIVE PARTICIPATION, INPUT, REVIEW AND COMMENT ON POLICY AND TECHNICAL ASPECTS OF SUPERFUND CLEANUPS IN ARIZONA INCLUDING REMEDIAL INVESTIGATION/FEASIBILITY STUDY, COMMUNITY PARTICIPATION, REMEDIAL DESIGN, OPERATIONS & MAINTENANCE, AND REMEDIAL ACTION OVERSIGHT. DESCRIPTION:THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT WILL FUND THE RECIPIENT, THE CALIFORNIA REGIONAL WATER QUALITY BOARD, LOS ANGELES REGION (REGIONAL BOARD), TO IMPLEMENT ITS CLEANUP PROGRAM IN THE SAN GABRIEL VALLEY. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE THE INVESTIGATION OF 262 BACKLOGGED CASES, ENROLLING CASES INTO ITS COST RECOVERY PROGRAM, CONTINUING TO REQUIRE AND OVERSEE SITE ASSESSMENT AND CLEANUP ACTIVITIES AT THE (POTENTIAL) SOURCE SITES, COMPLETION OF SITE ASSESSMENT AND CLEANUP ACTIVITIES, AND OPENING NEW CASES AT POTENTIAL SOURCE SITES. THE REGIONAL BOARD'S OVERSIGHT OF ASSESSMENT AND CLEANUP OF (POTENTIAL) SOURCE SITES WILL CONTRIBUTE TO THE GROUNDWATER CLEANUP OPERATIONS BEING CONDUCTED IN THE BALDWIN PARK, EL MONTE, SOUTH EL MONTE, AND PUENTE VALLEY OPERABLE UNITS IN ADDRESSING CONTAMINATION AT SOURCES SITES, PREVENTING FURTHER CONTAMINATION OF GROUNDWATER, AND ACCELERATING THE CLEANUP OF GROUNDWATER IN THE OPERABLE UNITS. THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT PROVIDES FULL FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $600,000.
ACTIVITIES:THE PROPOSED WORK IN THIS AGREEMENT INCLUDES CONTINUED INVESTIGATION AND CLEANUP OF CONTAMINATION IN THE SAN GABRIEL VALLEY. SUPPORTED WORK IS DIVIDED INTO FIVE KEY TASKS AND THEIR ASSOCIATED ACTIVITIES: (1) SITE INSPECTIONS AND EVALUATIONS; (2) MANAGEMENT OF BACKLOGGED SITES AND CONFIRMATION OF NEW SITES RESPONSIBLE FOUND RESPONSIBLE FOR RELEASING CONTAMINATION; (3) REMOVAL OF SOURCE CONTAMINATION; (4) ENFORCEMENT ACTIVITIES; AND (5) MANAGEMENT OF THE GRANT. 
SUPPORTED GRANT ACTIVITIES UNDER THESE TASKS INCLUDE DETERMINING WHERE SITE OR FACILITY INVESTIGATIONS MIGHT BE WARRANTED; REVIEWING DOCUMENTS LOOKING FOR EVIDENCE THAT CHEMICALS OF CONCERN (COCS) WERE USED, STORED, AND OR DISPOSED OF AT SPECIFIC SITES IN SAN GABRIEL VALLEY; CONDUCTING INSPECTIONS OF SITES SUSPECTED OF RELEASING CONTAMINATION; SAMPLING AT LOCATIONS EXPECTED TO BE CONTAMINATED; REQUIRING SOURCE REMOVAL ACTIONS IN SOIL, SOIL GAS, AND/OR GROUNDWATER THAT POSE AN IMMEDIATE AND CONTINUING THREAT TO HUMAN HEALTH, GROUNDWATER RESOURCES, AND/OR THE ENVIRONMENT; CONDUCTING ENFORCEMENT ACTIONS AGAINST ENTITIES WHO ARE FOUND TO HAVE VIOLATED ENVIRONMENTAL REGULATIONS; GRANT ADMINISTRATION INCLUDING, TRACKING ACTIVITIES, REPORTING ON PROGRESS, AND MAINTAINING REGULAR COMMUNICATIONS WITH USEPA. 

KEY TERMS: DRINKING WATER QUALITY, SOIL VAPOR, VAPOR INTRUSION, GROUNDWATER CONTAMINATION, VOLATILE ORGANIC COMPOUNDS (VOCS), TRICHLOROETHENE (TCE), PERCHLOROETHYLENE (PCE)
SUBRECIPIENT:NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.OUTCOMES:ANTICIPATED DELIVERABLES, EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO:
- INVESTIGATION AND IDENTIFICATION OF POTENTIAL NEW SOURCE SITES
- REDUCTION OF THE NUMBER OF POTENTIALLY LIABLE PARTIES OR FACILITIES ON THE BACKLOG LIST
- REDUCTION OF GROUNDWATER CONTAMINATION IN THE SAN GABRIEL VALLEY

DIRECT BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE RESIDENTS OF THE SAN GABRIEL VALLEY WHO DEPEND UPON THE SAN GABRIEL VALLEY AQUIFER AS THEIR PRIMARY DRINKING WATER SOURCE.

ACTIVITIES:ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDE THE FOLLOWING SUPPORT AGENCY ACTIVITIES: CDFW WILL CONDUCT ON-WATER, DOCKSIDE, SHORE SIDE AND COMMERCIAL FISH BUSINESS INSPECTIONS TO ENSURE ADHERENCE OF EXISTING WHITE CROAKER CATCH BAN AREA AND CATCH LIMIT. DESCRIPTION:THIS PROJECT WILL ALLOW THE WASHOE TRIBE OF NEVADA AND CALIFORNIA TO SUPPORT SUPERFUND RI/FS, DECISION-MAKING, AND RD/RA EFFORTS BY PRESENTING TO EPA SPECIALIZED INPUT REGARDING TRIBAL PERSPECTIVES, TRADITIONAL ECOLOGICAL KNOWLEDGE, AND TRIBAL CULTURAL RESOURCES.  THIS ACTION IS OFFERED AS AN ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT TO ENHANCE THE EFFECTIVENESS OF THE WASHOE TRIBE OF NEVADA AND CALIFORNIA IN PARTICIPATING IN THE SUPERFUND INVESTIGATION AND CLEANUP PROCESS AT THE LEVIATHAN MINE SITE, WHICH IS LOCATED NEAR TRIBAL LANDS AND WHICH MAY IMPACT TRIBAL RESOURCES. THE STATEMENT OF WORK INDICATES JOINT COLLABORATION WITH EPA AND MEETS THE CRITERIA FOR 'SUBSTANTIAL INVOLVEMENT'. THEREFORE, THE INSTRUMENT IS A COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT AND EPA R9 SUPERFUND DIVISION ANTICIPATES SUBSTANTIAL INVOLVEMENT WITH THE RECIPIENT.

UNDER CERCLA SECTION 104(D) AN INDIAN TRIBE MAY APPLY TO CARRY OUT SUPERFUND REMEDIAL INVESTIGATIONS AND RESPONSE ACTIONS. IF EPA DETERMINES THAT THE INDIAN TRIBE HAS THE CAPABILITY TO CARRY OUT ANY OR ALL OF SUCH ACTIONS, EPA MAY ENTER INTO A CONTRACT OR COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT WITH THE INDIAN TRIBE TO CARRY OUT SUCH ACTIONS. EPA USES COOPERATIVE AGREEMENTS TO TRANSFER FUNDS TO INDIAN TRIBES THAT ASSUME RESPONSIBILITY AS THE LEAD OR SUPPORT AGENCY FOR SUPERFUND RESPONSES. IN THE CASE OF THE LEVIATHAN MINE SITE, THE EPA R9 SUPERFUND DIVISION HAS DETERMINED THAT THE WASHOE TRIBE OF NEVADA AND CALIFORNIA HAS THE CAPABILITY TO PROVIDE SPECIALIZED TECHNICAL INPUT REGARDING INVESTIGATION AND CLEANUP DECISIONS SPECIFICALLY AS RELATES TO THE SITE'S POTENTIAL IMPACT ON TRIBAL RESOURCES. THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT PROVIDES FULL FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $154,957.

ACTIVITIES:ACTIVITIES INCLUDE BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO THE FOLLOWING ACTIVITIES/TASKS: PARTICIPATING IN MEETINGS RELATED TO THE LEVIATHAN MINE SITE; REVIEWING AND COMMENTING ON WORK PLANS, REPORTS, AND OTHER DOCUMENTS, INCLUDING THE RISK ASSESSMENTS RELATED TO THE LEVIATHAN MINE SITE, CONDUCTING OUTREACH TO THE TRIBAL COMMUNITY AND PUBLIC, PARTICIPATING IN SITE VISITS AND WORK SUCH AS CULTURAL MONITORING.SUBRECIPIENT:NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.OUTCOMES:DELIVERABLES INCLUDE REGULAR REPORTING TO EPA AND BRIEFING/UPDATES TO TRIBAL LEADERSHIP BY ENVIRONMENTAL STAFF; PRESENTATIONS AND OTHER OUTREACH TO THE COMMUNITY; TECHNICAL COMMENTS ON SITE RELATED DOCUMENTS; COMMENTS ON PROPOSED PLANS; AND CONSULTATION WITH EPA ON DECISIONS AND CULTURAL HERITAGE AND PRESERVATION. THE BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE THE WASHOE TRIBAL GOVERNMENT AND COMMUNITY.

DESCRIPTION:THE SUPERFUND CONSOLIDATED COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT (SCCA) GRANT PROVIDES THE BASE TECHNICAL AND ADMINISTRATIVE INFRASTRUCTURE FOR STATE AND FEDERAL CORRECTIVE ACTION ACTIVITIES PERFORMED BY STATE PERSONNEL TO IMPLEMENT THE CARSON RIVER MERCURY SITE (CRMS) OU1 ROD, ASSIST WITH THE SUPERFUND PROCESS FOR OU2, AND INVESTIGATE OTHER AREAS OF CONCERN WITHIN THE SITE FOOTPRINT OR AREAS POTENTIALLY IMPACTED BY THE SITE. THE SCCA GRANT FUNDING ALLOWS THE BUREAU OF CORRECTIVE ACTIONS (BCA) A DEPARTMENT WITH THE NEVADA DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION, TO MAINTAIN THE EXISTING PROGRAM AND ASSIST WITH DEVELOPMENT, IMPLEMENTATION, AND ADMINISTRATION OF OTHER INITIATIVES THAT WILL STRENGTHEN THE PROGRAM WITHIN THE STATE. WITHOUT SUSTAINED FUNDING, THE PROPOSED INITIATIVES IN THE WORK PLAN CANNOT BE IMPLEMENTED AND THE PROGRAM WILL STAGNATE OR BE RETIRED. 

ACTIVITIES:PARTICIPATE IN PROJECT MEETINGS, SUBMIT QUARTERLY REPORTS, IMPLEMENT THE OPERABLE UNIT 1 RECORD OF DECISION ESPECIALLY THE LONG-TERM SAMPLING AND RESPONSE PLAN, WORK TOWARDS THE OPERABLE UNIT 2 RECORD OF DECISION, COMMUNITY INVOLVEMENT, GIS DATABASE MANAGEMENTSUBRECIPIENT:NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.OUTCOMES:AN UPDATED GIS GEODATABASE AND STORYMAP, REGULAR COMMUNICATION WITH EPA AND STAKEHOLDERS, COMMUNITY INCLUDING RESIDENTS ON OR NEAR THE SUPERFUND SITE, REVIEWED SAMPLING PLANS, REVIEWED REMEDIATION PLANS.

DESCRIPTION:THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT FUNDS $800,000 TO THE STATE OF UTAH'S DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY. THIS PURPOSE OF THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT IS TO CONDUCT ADDITIONAL GROUNDWATER AND SOURCE AREA INVESTIGATION WORK, FFS, PP, AND ROD AMENDMENT TO DETERMINE PCE CONCENTRATIONS. 


ACTIVITIES:THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS NARRATIVE IS TO ALLOW THE STATE OF UTAH THROUGH ITS DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY (UDEQ) TO CONDUCT ADDITIONAL GROUNDWATER AND SOURCE AREA INVESTIGATION WORK, FOCUSED FEASIBILITY STUDY (FFS), PROPOSED PLAN (PP), AND RECORD OF DECISION (ROD) AMENDMENT, FOR THE FIVE POINTS PCE PLUME SITE.SUBRECIPIENT:NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.OUTCOMES:UDEQ WILL CONDUCT PROJECT MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES THAT MAY INCLUDE, BUT NOT BE LIMITED TO, COORDINATION WITH THE EPA ACCORDING TO THE SUPERFUND MEMORANDUM OF AGREEMENT (SMOA); WOODS CROSS CITY AND THE CITY OF NORTH SALT LAKE; THE UTAH ATTORNEY GENERAL'S OFFICE; AND OTHER STAKEHOLDERS. UDEQ WILL COORDINATE WITH EPA ALL COMMUNITY INVOLVEMENT ACTIVITIES WHICH MAY INCLUDE, BUT NOT BE LIMITED TO, ACQUIRING ACCESS FOR PERFORMING THE GROUNDWATER AND SOURCE AREA INVESTIGATION WORK, PREPARATION OF FACT SHEETS AND PUBLIC NOTICES, CONDUCTING PUBLIC MEETINGS, BRIEFING LOCAL GOVERNMENT OFFICIALS, AND COORDINATING ACTIVITIES WITH COMMUNITY GROUPS. UDEQ WILL MANAGE CONTRACTOR WORK ASSIGNMENTS AND REVIEW AND COMMENT ON RELEVANT PROJECT DOCUMENTS. INSTALLATION, SAMPLING, AND ANALYSIS OF SOIL GAS SAMPLE POINTS FOR A PERIOD OF THREE DAYS OR UP TO 15 SAMPLE POINTS TO A DEPTH OF 100 FEET, IF POSSIBLE, TO RE-EVALUATE SOURCE AREA CONTAMINATION AT DEPTH. THE RESULTS OF THE SOIL GAS SAMPLES WILL BE USED TO GUIDE THE LOCATION AND INSTALLATION OF FIVE ADDITIONAL MONITORING WELLS. INSTALLATION OF FIVE NEW GROUNDWATER MONITORING WELLS TO ADDRESS DATA GAPS IDENTIFIED IN THE MAY 2022 FIVE POINTS PCE PLUME SITE MONITORING AND REMEDIATION OPTIMIZATION SYSTEM (MAROS) STATISTICAL EVALUATION AND DATA REVIEW REPORT. UDEQ, WITH ASSISTANCE OF THE LOE CONTRACTOR, WILL CONDUCT ANNUAL GROUNDWATER MONITORING AND SAMPLING OF 14 EXISTING PERIMETER MONITORING WELLS, SEMI-ANNUAL MONITORING OF FIVE EXISTING PLUME CORE MONITORING WELLS (I.E., MW-101, MW-104, MW-105; MW 106; AND MW 108), AND QUARTERLY MONITORING OF THE FIVE NEW MONITORING WELLS FROM TASK 5, IN ORDER TO SUPPORT STATISTICAL EVALUATION OF GROUNDWATER DATA AND DEVELOPMENT OF THE FFS. UDEQ, WITH ASSISTANCE OF THE LOE CONTRACTOR WILL PERFORM A STATISTICAL EVALUATION OF GROUNDWATER MONITORING AND SAMPLING RESULTS COLLECTED OVER A TWO-YEAR PERIOD AND COMPLETE AN INVESTIGATION SUMMARY REPORT. UDEQ, WITH ASSISTANCE OF THE LOE CONTRACTOR WILL COMPLETE A FFS TO ESTABLISH NEW REMEDIAL ACTION OBJECTIVES AND TO IDENTIFY, EVALUATE, AND COMPARE POTENTIAL REMEDIES. UDEQ WILL PREPARE A PROPOSED PLAN IDENTIFYING THE PREFERRED ALTERNATIVE IDENTIFIED IN THE FFS AND CONDUCT A PUBLIC MEETING REGARDING THE PLAN. THE UDEQ WILL PREPARE A RECORD OF DECISION AMENDMENT AND MAY UTILIZE CONTRACTOR SUPPORT IN PERFORMING THIS TASK. DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROGRAM INCLUDE THE CITIES OF WOODS CROSS, BOUNTIFUL, DAVIS COUNTY AND THE RESIDENTS OF UTAH.

DESCRIPTION:THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT FUNDS $650,000 TO THE STATE OF COLORADO'S DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC HEALTH AND ENVIRONMENT. CDPHE WILL BE THE LEAD AGENCY FOR THE REMEDIAL DESIGN FOR TASK 3, EX-SITU MINE-WATER TREATMENT, AT THE CAPTAIN JACK MILL SUPERFUND SITE. THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT WILL ALLOW THE STATE OF COLORADO TO RETAIN AN ARCHITECT/ENGINEER (A/E) TO IMPLEMENT REMEDIAL DESIGN. THE TASKS ASSOCIATED WITH THE A/E'S CONTRACT WILL INCLUDE TREATABILITY STUDIES (IF NECESSARY), DEVELOPMENT OF DESIGN DOCUMENTS, CONSTRUCTION BIDDING ASSISTANCE, AND CONSTRUCTION OVERSIGHT.ACTIVITIES:ACTIVITIES INCLUDED IN THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT INCLUDE TREATABILITY STUDIES (IF NECESSARY), DEVELOPMENT OF DESIGN DOCUMENTS, CONSTRUCTION BIDDING ASSISTANCE, AND CONSTRUCTION OVERSIGHT.

THE MONITORING DATA COLLECTED SHOWS THAT THE IN-SITU NEUTRALIZATION AND TREATMENT PROGRAM HAS BEEN INADEQUATE TO MEET STANDARDS, THEREFORE ADDITIONAL DESIGN ACTIONS WILL BE UNDERTAKEN TO EVALUATE ADDITIONAL TREATMENT MEASURES FOR THE IMPOUNDED MINE POOL. THE ANTICIPATED TREATMENT PROCESS IS AN EX-SITU SULFATE REDUCING BIOREACTOR. HOWEVER, THE SPECIFIC TYPE AND DESIGN OF THE EX-SITU TREATMENT NEEDS TO BE DETERMINED. TO ASSIST IN THE DESIGN, ADDITIONAL TREATABILITY STUDIES (BENCH OR PILOT SCALE) MAY BE CONDUCTED ON THE MINE POOL WATER.

THIS TASK WILL INCLUDE PREPARATION OF CONSTRUCTION DOCUMENTS FOR THE EX-SITU TREATMENT SYSTEM, ASSISTANCE DURING THE PROCUREMENT PROCESS AND OVERSIGHT OF THE CONSTRUCTION. IT WILL INCLUDE CONSTRUCTION DOCUMENTS FOR ALL COMPONENTS NECESSARY FOR THE EX-SITU TREATMENT SYSTEM.SUBRECIPIENT:NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.OUTCOMES:THE REMEDIAL DESIGN OBJECTIVES DEVELOPED FOR THIS CAPTAIN JACK MILL REMEDIAL DESIGN INCLUDE PREPARING DESIGN DOCUMENTS FOR THE CONSTRUCTION OF THE SELECTED REMEDY OUTLINED IN RECORD OF DECISION (ROD) DATED APRIL 29, 2008 FOR TASK 3. THE SELECTED REMEDY DETAILED IN THE SITE ROD INCLUDED TWO COMPONENTS: SURFACE CONTAMINATION REMEDIATION AND SUBSURFACE CONTAMINATION REMEDIATION. THE SUBSURFACE CONTAMINATION REMEDIATION WAS FURTHER BROKEN INTO TWO PHASES: IN-SITU MINE-POOL TREATMENT AND EX-SITU MINE-POOL TREATMENT. FOR EASE OF DISCUSSION, THESE REMEDIAL ELEMENTS HAVE BEEN INFORMALLY REFERRED TO AS TASK 1 (SURFACE REMEDY), TASK 2 (IN-SITU TREATMENT) AND TASK 3 (EX-SITU TREATMENT). DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROGRAM INCLUDE BOULDER COUNTY AND THE RESIDENTS OF COLORADO.

ACTIVITIES:TASK 1 - PROJECT MANAGEMENT
TASK 2 - REMEDIAL ACTION/SVE INSTALLATION
TASK 3 - REMEDIAL ACTION (SVE)/MONITORING/REPORTING
TASK 4 - CONTRACTUAL PROJECT MANAGEMENT
SUBRECIPIENT:NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.OUTCOMES:TASKS TO BE COMPLETED UNDER THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT ARE AS FOLLOWS:
TASK 1 - PROJECT MANAGEMENT
#9679; THE DERR WILL CONDUCT PROJECT MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES THAT MAY INCLUDE, BUT NOT BE LIMITED TO, COORDINATION WITH THE EPA ACCORDING TO THE SUPERFUND MEMORANDUM OF AGREEMENT AND THE SSC. #9679; THE DERR WILL COORDINATE MEETINGS WITH THE EPA AND CONTRACTORS TO DISCUSS PROJECT MANAGEMENT, SCHEDULES AND THE BUDGET. ON A CASE-BY-CASE BASIS, CERTAIN MEETINGS WILL NEED TO BE DOCUMENTED WHEN A DECISION AND/OR FOLLOW-UP ITEMS ARE AGREED TO. #9679; THE DERR SHALL SUBMIT CONTRACTOR'S MONTHLY PROGRESS REPORTS TO THE EPA REMEDIAL
PROJECT MANAGER (RPM) WITHIN 30 CALENDAR DAYS FOLLOWING THE END OF EACH MONTH. THE REPORT WILL INCLUDE A NARRATIVE OF WORK PERFORMED DURING THE REPORTING PERIOD, A FINANCIAL STATUS REPORT FOR THE WORK ACTIVITIES, CURRENT AND ESTIMATED PROJECT COSTS DURING THE REPORTING PERIOD, AS WELL AS MONTHLY AND CUMULATIVE COST DATA ON EXPENDITURES, BUDGETS, AND VARIANCES FOR THE WORK PERFORMED. THE RPM SHALL NOTIFY THE STATE PROJECT MANAGER (SPM) AS SOON AS PRACTICABLE UPON RECEIPT OF THE MONTHLY PROGRESS REPORT WITH ANY 3 CONCERNS. WRITTEN NOTIFICATION OF SUCH CONCERNS SHALL BE PROVIDED BY THE RPM TO SPM WITHIN 30 CALENDAR DAYS PRIOR TO THE INITIATION OF ALL FIELD ACTIVITIES. TASK 2 - REMEDIAL ACTION/SVE INSTALLATION - SVE INSTALLATION WILL INCLUDE INSTALLING TWO SHALLOW AND FIVE DEEP SVE WELLS IN THE VADOSE ZONES OF THE SOURCE AREA. - AN SVE SYSTEM BUILDING WILL BE CONSTRUCTED AND HOUSE THE CONTROL SYSTEM TO OPERATE THE SVE WELLS. TASK 3 - REMEDIAL ACTION (SVE)/MONITORING/REPORTING #9679; REVISE AND UPDATE BASELINE AND LONG TERM MONITORING PLAN (LTMP) ASSOCIATED WITH SOIL VAPOR SAMPLING AND REPORTING, WHICH PER THE LTMP REQUIRES A SET OF WELLS TO BE SAMPLING ANNUALLY AND AN ADDITIONAL SET OF WELLS TO BE SAMPLED BIENNIALLY. #9679; DERR, WITH SUPPORT FROM THE LOE CONTRACTOR WILL CONDUCT MONITORING OF THE SVE SYSTEM (ANTICIPATED TO OPERATE FOR UP TO FIVE YEARS). SVE MONITORING, PER THE DESIGN DOCUMENTS, REQUIRES THE FOLLOWING: O WEEKLY VISITS FOR SVE SYSTEM MONITORING FOR THE FIRST MONTH TO MONITOR AND ADJUST SVE SYSTEM OPERATING PARAMETERS (FLOW RATES AND WELL HEAD VACUUM). O MONTHLY VISITS FOR SVE SYSTEM MONITORING AFTER THE FIRST MONTH. O MONTHLY SVE PROCESS VAPOR SAMPLING AND REPORTING TO UDAQ TO CONFIRM THAT EXEMPTION REQUIREMENTS ARE MET (MAY BE ABLE TO BE REDUCED TO QUARTERLY OR SEMIANNUAL REPORTING WITH UDAQ APPROVAL). O MONTHLY VOC MONITORING AT SVE EXTRACTION WELLS TO MONITOR REMEDIAL PROGRESS. O QUARTERLY VOC MONITORING AT ALL VAPOR MONITORING POINTS. #9679; REMEDIAL ACTION REPORT AND FINAL CLOSE OUT REPORT. TASK 4 - CONTRACTUAL PROJECT MANAGEMENT #9679; DERR WILL COORDINATE WORK ASSIGNMENTS, WORK PLANS, BUDGETS AND SCHEDULES WITH THE CONTRACTOR, AND REVIEW MONTHLY INVOICES. MONTHLY PROGRESS REPORTS, DRAFT WORK ASSIGNMENTS AND WORK PLANS AND SCHEDULES WILL BE PROVIDED TO THE EPA RPM FOR REVIEW AND COMMENT. #9679; DERR WILL MANAGE CONTRACTOR WORK ACTIVITIES SUCH AS THE MONITORING OF THE SVE WELLS AND VAPOR MONITORING POINTS

DESCRIPTION:
THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT FUNDS $12,258,000 TO THE STATE OF UTAH'S DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY (UDEQ) WITH THE INFRASTRUCTURE INVESTMENT AND JOBS ACT OF 2021. UDEQ WILL BE THE LEAD AGENCY FOR THE REMEDIAL ACTION AT OPERABLE UNIT TWO (OU2) OF THE JACOBS SMELTER SUPERFUND SITE. THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT WILL REDUCE RISKS FROM EXPOSURE TO LEAD AND ARSENIC-CONTAMINATED SOIL.


ACTIVITIES:
THE ACTIONS TO BE PERFORMED AT JACOBS SMELTER OU2 REMEDIAL ACTION INCLUDE: 1. REMOVAL OF EXISTING VEGETATION FROM THE CONTAMINATED AREAS; 2. EXCAVATION OF SURFACE (6 INCHES) SOILS EXCEEDING 500 MG/KG LEAD AND SUBSURFACE SOILS (TO 18 INCHES) EXCEEDING 800 MG/KG IN RESIDENTIAL AREAS (5.4 ACRES); 3. EXCAVATION OF SURFACE AND SUBSURFACE SOILS WITH LEAD CONCENTRATIONS EXCEEDING 3,000 MG/KG IN UNDEVELOPED AREAS (26.3 ACRES); 4. EXCAVATION OF ALL PRINCIPAL THREAT WASTE; 5. TRANSPORTATION TO AND DISPOSAL OF ALL EXCAVATED SOIL AT AN APPROPRIATE LANDFILL; AND 6. PLACEMENT OF CLEAN TOPSOIL AND RE-VEGETATION OF EXCAVATED AREAS.

OUTCOMES:
THE REMEDIAL ACTION OBJECTIVES (RAOS) DEVELOPED FOR OU2 ARE AS FOLLOWS: 1. REDUCE RISKS FROM EXPOSURE TO LEAD AND ARSENIC-CONTAMINATED SOIL, SUCH THAT NO MORE THAN FIVE PERCENT (5%) OF CHILDREN EXPOSED TO SITE CONTAMINANTS WILL HAVE A BLOOD LEAD CONCENTRATIONS EXCEEDING 10 MICROGRAMS PER DECILITER (UG/DL).  SINCE THE LEAD AND ARSENIC CONTAMINATION IS CO-LOCATED, HEALTH RISKS ASSOCIATED WITH ARSENIC EXPOSURE WILL BE ADDRESSED BY THE REMEDIATION OF LEAD CONTAMINATION. THIS OBJECTIVE CAN BE ACHIEVED BY PREVENTING THE INGESTION OF LEAD AND ARSENIC CONTAMINATED SOILS ABOVE CLEAN-UP LEVELS IN RESIDENTIAL AND UNDEVELOPED AREAS;  2. REDUCE RISKS FROM EXPOSURE TO LEAD CONTAMINATED SOIL SUCH THAT NO ECOLOGICAL RECEPTOR HAS THE POTENTIAL TO EXCEED TWO TIMES THE TOXICITY EXPOSURE THRESHOLDS FOR NON-CANCER HEALTH EFFECTS. THIS OBJECTIVE CAN BE ACHIEVED BY PREVENTING THE INGESTION OF LEAD-CONTAMINATED SOILS BY ECOLOGICAL RECEPTORS THAT WOULD RESULT IN AN AVERAGE EXPOSURE IN EXCESS OF 1,148 MG/KG LEAD; AND 3. DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROGRAM INCLUDE TOOELE COUNTY AND THE RESIDENTS OF UTAH.

NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.

TASK 2: DESIGN THE SPECIFIC SOURCE CONTROL ACTIONS REQUIRED AT THE LUCKY JOE, JUSTICE, BLUE BOY, ARMSTRONG, AND POCAHONTAS MINES. CONTRACTOR WILL REVIEW MINES OF CONCERNS SPECIFIC INFORMATION AND DESIGN APPROPRIATE CONTROL ACTIONS FOR EACH.
TASK 3: DESIGN THE SPECIFIC SURFACE WATER RUN#8208;ON SOURCE CONTROL ACTIONS FOR THE BEATRICE MINE SITES. CONTRACTOR WILL REVIEW MINES OF CONCERNS SPECIFIC INFORMATION AND DESIGN APPROPRIATE CONTROL ACTIONS FOR EACH.
TASK 4: FINALIZE THE DESIGN FOR THE REMOVAL ACTION ALONG THE IRRIGATION DITCH ON THE RV RANCH. CONTRACTOR WILL REVISE THE DESIGN FOR REMEDIAL WORK WITH THE RV RANCH.
TASK 5: DEVELOP BID DOCUMENTS FOR THE EXCAVATION AND TRANSPORT OF THE RV RANCH STOCKPILE TO LUTTRELL AND RECLAMATION OF THE STOCKPILE AREA. CONTRACTOR WILL DEVELOP FINAL DESIGN DOCUMENTS FOR THE EMACS SYSTEM.
TASK 6: DEVELOP FINAL DESIGN DOCUMENTS TO BID FOR REMEDIAL ACTION FROM TASKS 2, 3, 4, AND 5. CONTRACTOR WILL DEVELOP FINAL DESIGN DOCUMENTS (INCLUDING IDENTIFIED HAUL ROUTES) FOR THE EMACS SYSTEM AND AN ENGINEER'S ESTIMATE FOR BID.
TASK 7: STATUS REPORTS. CONTRACTOR WILL PREPARE STATUS REPORTS AS OUTLINED BY DEQ.
TASK 8: PROVIDE ADDITIONAL TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE AS NEEDED. AT DEQ'S REQUEST, CONTRACTOR SHALL PROVIDE ADDITIONAL TECHNICAL SUPPORT TO DEQ. WORK MAY INCLUDE, BUT MAY NOT BE LIMITED TO, TECHNICAL SUPPORT IN REVIEW OF DOCUMENTS AND PREPARATION OF COMMENTS, MEETING ATTENDANCE, OVERSIGHT OF AND PARTICIPATION IN ONSITE ACTIVITIES, COORDINATION WITH EPA AND USFS, AND OTHER TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE AS REQUESTED BY DEQ.

DESCRIPTION:THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT FUNDS THE RECIPIENT'S PROGRAM TO PERFORM SITE CHARACTERIZATION ACTIVITIES SUCH AS PRELIMINARY ASSESSMENTS AND SITE INSPECTION AT POTENTIAL OR CONFIRMED HAZARDOUS WASTE SITES.ACTIVITIES:ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDE THE FOLLOWING SITE ASSESSMENT RELATED ACTIONS: PRE-CERCLIS SCREENING, PRELIMINARY ASSESSMENTS, SITE INSPECTIONS, AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE.SUBRECIPIENT:NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.OUTCOMES:ANTICIPATED OUTCOMES AND EXPECTED DELIVERABLES INCLUDE COMPLETION OF ONE (1) EXPANDED SITE INSPECTION, ONE (1) CERCLIS PRE-SCREENING, TWO (2) PRELIMINARY ASSESSMENTS, AND TWO (2) SITE INSPECTIONS. THE PURPOSE OF THIS FUNDED SUPPORT AGENCY COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT IS TO ENSURE DELAWARE DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES AND ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION&RSQUOANDS MEANINGFUL AND SUBSTANTIAL INVOLVEMENT IN RESPONSE ACTIVITIES AS SPECIFIED IN CERCLA 121(F)(1).  THE ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED ARE TO ASSIST IN THE OVERSIGHT OF THE REMEDIAL INVESTIGATION/FEASIBILITY STUDY (RIFS) OPERABLE UNIT 3.  THE DELIVERABLES INCLUDE TIMELY INPUT TO SUPPORT THE REGULATORY OVERSIGHT, TECHNICAL REVIEW OF DOCUMENTATION, PARTICIPATION IN MEETINGS, AND EVALUATION OF INFORMATION.  THE EXPECTED OUTCOMES AND INTENDED BENEFICIARY ARE TO ENSURE TECHNICAL STATE REQUIREMENTS ARE ADDRESSED AND ENSURE STATE AND COMMUNITY CONCERNS ARE ADDRESSED. THE RIFS ACTIVITIES WILL HELP PROVIDE BETTER LEADERSHIP AND MANAGEMENT TO PROPERLY CLEAN UP CONTAMINATED SITES TO REVITALIZE AND RETURN THE LAND BACK TO COMMUNITIES IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE FY2018-2022 STRATEGIC PLAN OF GOAL 1. THERE ARE NO SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES FOR THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT IS TO ENSURE WEST VIRGINIA DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTIONS MEANINGFUL AND SUBSTANTIAL INVOLVEMENT IN RESPONSE ACTIVITIES AS SPECIFIED IN CERCLA 121(F)(1). THE ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDE ASSISTING IN THE REMOVAL EVALUATION OF THE W&AMPANDG ELECTROPLATING SITE TO ENSURE HAZARDOUS SUBSTANCES ARE NOT BEING RELEASED INTO THE ENVIRONMENT. THE DELIVERABLES INCLUDE TIMELY INPUT TO SUPPORT THE REGULATORY OVERSIGHT, TECHNICAL REVIEW OF DOCUMENTATION, PARTICIPATION IN MEETINGS, AND EVALUATION OF INFORMATION. THE EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE ENSURING HAZARDOUS SUBSTANCES ARE NOT BEING RELEASED FROM THE SITE AT LEVELS WHICH WOULD BE OF CONCERN, HELPING MAINTAIN CONTROL OF CONDITIONS AT THE SITE, AND PROTECTING HUMAN HEALTH AND THE ENVIRONMENT.  DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROGRAM INCLUDE MARION AND TAYLOR COUNTIES.  THE REMOVAL ASSESSMENT PHASE IS IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE FY2018-2022 STRATEGIC PLAN OF GOAL 1. THE PURPOSE OF THIS FUNDED SUPPORT AGENCY COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT IS TO ENSURE MARYLAND DEPARTMENT OF THE ENVIRONMENT&RSQUOANDS MEANINGFUL AND SUBSTANTIAL INVOLVEMENT IN RESPONSE ACTIVITIES AS SPECIFIED IN CERCLA 121(F)(1).  THE ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED ARE TO ASSIST IN THE OVERSIGHT OF THE REMEDIAL DESIGN AT THE 68TH STREET DUMP INDUSTRIAL ENTERPRISES SITE FOR THE OPERABLE UNIT ONE.  THE DELIVERABLES INCLUDE TIMELY INPUT TO SUPPORT THE REGULATORY OVERSIGHT, TECHNICAL REVIEW OF DOCUMENTATION, PARTICIPATION IN MEETINGS, AND EVALUATION OF INFORMATION.  THE EXPECTED OUTCOMES AND INTENDED BENEFICIARY ARE TO ENSURE TECHNICAL STATE REQUIREMENTS ARE ADDRESSED AND ENSURE STATE AND COMMUNITY CONCERNS ARE ADDRESSED.  THE REMEDIAL DESIGN PROVIDES THE BASIS FOR THE REMEDIAL ACTION WHICH WILL FULFILL THE REMEDY SELECTION PHASE IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE FY2018-2022 STRATEGIC PLAN OF GOAL ONE.  THERE ARE NO SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES FOR THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT.

WORK SCOPE
MDEQ WILL ISSUE A REMEDIAL ACTION CONSTRUCTION CONTRACT TO COMPLETE THE FOLLOWING WORK:
#61607;	PREPARING PRE-CONSTRUCTION SUBMITTALS PRIOR TO CONSTRUCTION ACTIVITIES FOR ALL WORK COVERED BY CONTRACT DOCUMENTS. 
#61607;	INSTALLING AND MAINTAINING EROSION AND SITE CONTROLS FOR ALL ASPECTS OF THE PROJECT.
#61607;	PERFORMING DUST CONTROL AND ROAD MAINTENANCE.
#61607;	CLEARING AND GRUBBING PROJECT WORK AREAS.
#61607;	IMPROVING ACCESS, AS NECESSARY, TO MINE SITES TO ALLOW FOR REMEDIAL CONSTRUCTION, INCLUDING HAUL ROADS AND BRIDGES.
#61607;	PERFORMING SURVEYING, INCLUDING CONSTRUCTION GRADE STAKING, PRE-AND POST-WASTE PLACEMENT SURVEYS, AND AS-BUILT SURVEY, FOR ALL PROJECT AREAS.
#61607;	PERFORMING MATERIALS TESTING FOR PROJECT MATERIALS, INCLUDING ON CONSTRUCTION MATERIALS (E.G. GRANULAR MATERIAL) AND COMPACTION TESTING ON PLACED MATERIALS.
#61607;	PERFORMING NECESSARY EXCAVATION AT THE SOLID MEDIA REMOVAL MINE SITES, WASTE STOCKPILE, AND RV RANCH IRRIGATION DITCHES TO REMOVE CONTAMINATED SOILS. EXCAVATED MATERIALS WILL BE HAULED TO THE LUTTRELL REPOSITORY FOR PLACEMENT AND DISPOSAL.
#61607;	GENERATION (SCREENING/CRUSHING) OF BACKFILL FILL MATERIALS FROM EXISTING STOCKPILED MATERIAL AT BASIN CREEK MINE, AND BACKFILL OF EXCAVATION AREAS AT SOLID MEDIA REMOVAL SITES.
#61607;	REMOVE REPOSITORY COVER AND PLACE WASTE FROM THE SOLID MEDIA REMOVAL SITES, IN ADDITION TO WASTE STAGED AT THE NORTH END OF THE REPOSITORY, INTO THE REPOSITORY. REPLACE WINTER COVER AFTER WASTE PLACEMENT IN THE REPOSITORY. 
#61607;	REVEGETATION OF ALL AREAS DISTURBED DURING CONSTRUCTION, INCLUDING GROWTH MEDIA PLACEMENT, SEEDING, AND HYDRO-MULCHING, AND INSTALLATION OF EROSION CONTROL BLANKETS, AS NECESSARY.
#61607;	THIS WORK ALSO INCLUDES CLEANING/REPAIR/INSTALLATION OF CULVERTS AS NECESSARY ON THE SITE OR THE ACCESS ROADS, AS IDENTIFIED BY THE ENGINEER.

DESCRIPTION:THIS ACTION APPROVES AN AWARD IN THE AMOUNT OF $485,000 TO THE SOUTH CAROLINA DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND ENVIRONMENTAL CONTROL (SCDHEC). THE PURPOSE OF THIS AGREEMENT IS TO PROVIDE FUNDING FOR THE OPERATION OF SCDHECS UNDERGROUND STORAGE TANK (UST) PROGRAM IN LEAK DETECTION, PREVENTION AND RELATED ENFORCEMENT. THE OBJECTIVES OF THE UST PROGRAM ARE: (1) ENCOURAGING OWNERS AND OPERATORS TO PROPERLY OPERATE AND MAINTAIN THEIR USTS; (2) ENSURING OWNERS AND OPERATORS MONITOR USTS IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE REGULATIONS; AND (3) DEVELOPING THE STATE PROGRAM TO OPERATE IN LIEU OF THE FEDERAL PROGRAM.  ACTIVITIES:ACTIVITIES PERFORMED INCLUDE BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO CONDUCTING APPROXIMATELY 1,333 FACILITY COMPLIANCE INSPECTIONS, PROVIDE COMPLIANCE ASSISTANCE TO THE FACILITIES AND CARRY-OUT ENFORCEMENT ACTIVITIES FOR ANY NON-COMPLIANCE ISSUES DISCOVERED. THIS ENABLES SCDHEC TO BE PROACTIVE IN PROMOTING UST COMPLIANCE IN HELPING TO ELIMINATE ANY RELEASES DUE TO POOR MAINTENANCE AND OPERATION, THUS REDUCING OR PREVENTING ENVIRONMENTAL CONTAMINATION.  SUBRECIPIENT:NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.OUTCOMES:EXPECTED DELIVERABLES/OUTCOMES INCLUDE BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO PROTECTING THE ENVIRONMENT BY PREVENTING PETROLEUM AND HAZARDOUS SUBSTANCE RELEASES.  ANOTHER OUTCOME IS THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA WILL CARRY OUT ITS UST PROGRAM TO PREVENT THE RELEASE OF REGULATED PRODUCTS FROM USTS INTO THE ENVIRONMENT AND TO ENFORCE VIOLATIONS OF PROGRAM PROVISIONS.  THESE EFFORTS WILL REDUCE RISK, IMPROVE ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION, AND RESTORE AND SUPPORT RECREATIONAL AND PUBLIC HEALTH ISSUES THAT CONTRIBUTE TO HEALTHY ECONOMIES. THESE RESULTS SUPPORT THE EPA'S STRATEGIC PLAN GOAL TO SAFEGUARD AND REVITALIZE COMMUNITIES, AND THE OBJECTIVE TO REDUCE OR PREVENT ENVIRONMENTAL CONTAMINATION. THE PRIMARY AND DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROGRAM ARE THE RESIDENTS IN THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA.

DESCRIPTION:THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT MAY FUND THE PARTICIPATION OF THE RECIPIENT IN ACTIVITIES INCLUDING BUT NOT LIMITED TO THE REVIEW OF REMEDIAL INVESTIGATION AND FEASIBILITY STUDIES, PROPOSED PLANS, AND RECORDS OF DECISION AT SUPERFUND SITES IN MARYLAND WHEN THE ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY (EPA) IS THE LEAD AGENCY FOR REMEDIAL ACTION. THIS CAN ALSO INCLUDE REVIEW OF INFORMATION, ATTENDING SITE-RELATED MEETINGS AND PARTICIPATING IN FIVE-YEAR REVIEWS.ACTIVITIES:ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDE THE FOLLOWING SUPPORT AGENCY ACTIVITIES: LONG-TERM MONITORING ACTIVITIES TO INCLUDE THE TIMELY INPUT TO SUPPORT THE REGULATORY OVERSIGHT, TECHNICAL REVIEW AND EVALUATION OF REMEDIAL ACTION ACTIVITIES AT THE SAND, GRAVEL AND STONE OPERABLE UNIT THREE SITE.  THE DETAILED TASKS INCLUDE FINANCIAL OVERSIGHT, ON-SITE COORDINATION WITH EPA, REVIEW OF DOCUMENTS, MEETINGS, CORRESPONDENCE, REGULAR COMMUNICATION WITH EPA AND THE PUBLIC, AND OTHER RELATED ACTIVITIES.SUBRECIPIENT:NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.OUTCOMES:ANTICIPATED OUTCOMES AND EXPECTED DELIVERABLES INCLUDE:  SEMI-ANNUAL REPORTS AND FINANCIAL OVERSIGHT TO PROVIDE EPA WITH A RECORD OF MARYLAND DEPARTMENT OF THE ENVIRONMENT'S (MDE) ACTIVITIES; VARIOUS MEETINGS TO ENSURE THE STATE AND COMMUNITY CONCERNS ARE ADDRESSED; PROVIDING APPLICABLE OR RELEVANT AND APPROPRIATE REQUIREMENTS TO ENSURE THAT STATE REQUIREMENTS ARE IDENTIFIED IN A TIMELY FASHION; COMMENTING ON THE TECHNICAL AND ADMINISTRATIVE CORRESPONDENCE RELATED TO THE REMEDIAL ACTION TO ENSURE THAT TECHNICAL STATE REQUIREMENTS ARE ADDRESSED; PROVIDEING FIELD SUPPORT AND OVERSIGHT TO ENSURE STATE AND COMMUNITY CONCERNS ARE ADDRESSED; AND COORDINATING THE REVIEW OF SITE-RELATED DOCUMENTS BY OTHER ADMINISTRATIONS WITHIN THE STATE AND MDE TO ENSURE STATE AND COMMUNITY CONCERNS ARE ADDRESSED.  THE INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE THE RESIDENTS OF THE STATE OF MARYLAND.

DESCRIPTION:THIS AGREEMENT MAY FUND THE PARTICIPATION OF THE RECIPIENT IN ACTIVITIES INCLUDING BUT NOT LIMITED TO THE REVIEW OF REMEDIAL INVESTIGATION AND FEASIBILITY STUDIES (RI/FS), PROPOSED PLANS, AND RECORDS OF DECISION AT SUPERFUND SITES IN MARYLAND WHEN THE ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY IS THE LEAD AGENCY FOR REMEDIAL ACTION. RELATED TO THE RI/FS DUE WITHIN THE AGREED UPON TIMEFRAME BETWEEN EPA AND MDE AT RECEIPT OF THE DOCUMENT/REQUEST TO ENSURE THAT TECHNICAL STATE REQUIREMENTS ARE ADDRESSED; PROVIDE APPLICABLE OR RELEVANT AND APPROPRIATE REQUIREMENTS DUE WITHIN TIMEFRAME AGREED BETWEEN EPA AND MDE AT RECEIPT OF THE DOCUMENT/REQUEST TO ENSURE THAT STATE ARARS ARE IDENTIFIED IN A TIMELY FASHION; PROVIDE FIELD SUPPORT AND OVERSIGHT AT THE TIME THE ACTIVITY IS UNDERWAY TO ENSURE THAT STATE AND COMMUNITY CONCERNS ARE ADDRESSED; AND, PARTICIPATE IN MEETINGS WITH THE EPA, POTENTIALLY RESPONSIBLE PARTIES AND THEIR CONTRACTORS, OTHER TECHNICAL OR LEGAL STAFF AND THE COMMUNITY AT THE TIME THE MEETING IS UNDERWAY TO ENSURE THAT SATE AND COMMUNITY CONCERNS ARE ADDRESSED.  THE INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE THE RESIDENTS OF THE STATE OF MARYLAND.

DESCRIPTION:THIS AGREEMENT FUNDS THE RECIPIENT'S PROGRAM TO PERFORM SITE CHARACTERIZATION ACTIVITIES SUCH AS PRELIMINARY ASSESSMENTS AND SITE INSPECTION (PA/SI) AT POTENTIAL OR CONFIRMED HAZARDOUS WASTE SITES AND ALSO TO ADDRESS CURRENT AND NEWLY DISCOVERED FORMERLY USED DEFENSE SITES (FUDS).ACTIVITIES:ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDE THE FOLLOWING SITE ASSESSMENT RELATED ACTIONS: PA/SI - PRE-COMPREHENSIVE ENVIRONMENTAL RESPONSE, COMPENSATION, AND LIABILITY INFORMATION SYSTEM SCREENINGS, PRELIMINARY ASSESSMENT/SITE INSPECTIONS, REMEDIAL INVESTIGATIONS AT POTENTIAL SITES FOR THE NATIONAL PRIORITY LIST, FUDS VIA CONTRACT, AND CONDUCT ENVIRONMENTAL FIELD WORK AND DOCUMENT FINDINGS FOR FUDS.SUBRECIPIENT:NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.OUTCOMES:ANTICIPATED OUTCOMES AND EXPECTED DELIVERABLES INCLUDE: PA/SI - SUBMIT SEMI-ANNUAL PROGRESS REPORTS; CONDUCT SITE VISITS AS NEEDED FOR SITE ASSESSMENT; REVIEW TECHNICAL DOCUMENTS, PARTICIPATE ON TELECONFERENCES AND MEETINGS AS NEEDED TO COMPLY WITH GRANT REQUIREMENTS, ENSURE QUALITY DELIVERABLES, AND KEEP EPA UPDATED ON SITE CONDITIONS AND STATUS.  FOR FUDS - PRIORITIZE 1 SITE ANNUALLY FOR FIELD INVESTIGATIVE SERVICES VIA CONTRACT MANAGEMENT SERVICES WHO WILL PROVIDE DRAFT SAMPLING AND ANALYSIS PLAN, DRAFT SITE SAMPLING REPORT AND ALL FINAL REPORTS; 
AT 2 SECONDARY SITES ANNUALLY - REVIEW HISTORICAL RECORDS, CLOSE OUT OR PRIORITIZE FOR FURTHER ACTION, SUBMIT INFORMATION TO DEVELOP PATH FORWARD FOR EACH SITE AND SUBMIT SEMI-ANNUAL PROGRESS REPORTS TO COMPLY WITH GRANT REQUIREMENTS, ENSURE STATE CONCERNS ARE ADDRESSED, ASSIST EPA WITH SITE EVALUATION, AND ENSURE ALL PRIMARY SITES ARE PROPERLY INVESTIGATED AND ALL SITES ARE SCORED TO DETERMINE ADDITIONAL ACTIONS NEEDED OR NO FURTHER ACTIONS NEEDED.  BENEFICIARIES ARE THE RESIDENTS OF THE COMMONWEALTH OF VIRGINIA.

DESCRIPTION:THIS AGREEMENT FUNDS THE FULL FY2023 MANAGEMENT ASSISTANCE PROGRAM IN THE AMOUNT OF $51,680.00 TO SUPPORT THE MINNESOTA PCA  IN ACTIVITIES INCLUDING BUT NOT LIMITED TO THE REVIEW OF REMEDIAL INVESTIGATION AND FEASIBILITY STUDIES, PROPOSED PLANS, AND RECORDS OF DECISION AT THE BURLINGTON NORTHERN TIE PLANT (BRAINERD/BAXTER PLANT), KURT MFG. CO., AND GENERAL MILLS SITES WHEN THE ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY (EPA) IS THE LEAD AGENCY FOR REMEDIAL ACTION. THIS CAN ALSO INCLUDE REVIEW OF INFORMATION, ATTENDING SITE-RELATED MEETINGS AND PARTICIPATING IN FIVE-YEAR REVIEWS.ACTIVITIES:PLANNED ACTIVITIES FOR THE PERIOD OF APRIL 1, 2023 - MARCH 31, 2024 INCLUDE: REVIEW MONTHLY PROGRESS REPORTS; REVIEW 2021 ANNUAL REPORT; REVIEW INFORMATION AND RESULTS SUBMITTED BY BNSF REGARDING THE ISB TREATABILITY STUDY; REVIEW CORRESPONDENCE AND INFORMATION SUBMITTED BY BNSF REGARDING SAMPLING EVENTS, MANAGEMENT, AND OPERATION AND MAINTENANCE OF SITE; REVIEW AND ASSISTANCE WITH COMPLETING INSTITUTIONAL CONTROL(S) (INCLUDING DRAFTS) FOR THE SITE.

SUBRECIPIENT:NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.OUTCOMES:THE ENVIRONMENTAL OUTPUTS/OUTCOMES AS A RESULT OF THE ASSISTANCE FOR THE 5.7 MILLION RESIDENTS OF THE STATE OF MINNESOTA ARE AS FOLLOWS: 1. REVIEW, DESIGN, OVERSIGHT, AND ANALYSIS OF THE SITE-WIDE OR MEDIA SPECIFIC INVESTIGATIONS/TESTS CONDUCTED; 2. REVIEW, DESIGN, OVERSIGHT, AND ANALYSIS OF INVESTIGATIVE WORK PLANS; 3. REVIEW OF THE SITE INVESTIGATIONS CONDUCTED BY THE PRPS, IF NECESSARY; 4. REVIEW OF THE FEASIBILITY STUDIES; 5. REVIEW OF THE PROPOSED PLANS AND RECORD OF DECISIONS OR ROD AMENDMENTS; 6. REVIEW OF THE REMEDIAL DESIGN AND REMEDIAL ACTION WORK PLANS. TO ACCOMPLISH THESE TASKS, THE MPCA WILL: REVIEW DOCUMENTS AND OTHER TASKS ASSOCIATED WITH THE REMEDIAL PROCESSES AT THE SITES AS REQUESTED BY EPA; HIRE A STATE CONSULTANT TO ASSIST WITH REVIEW OF THE FS, REMEDIAL DESIGN, REMEDIAL ACTION AND ASSOCIATED DOCUMENTS AS NEEDED; AND FORM A MPCA TEAM CONSISTING OF A PROJECT MANAGER, HYDROGEOLOGIST; AND IF NEEDED, HUMAN HEALTH RISK ASSESSOR, ECOLOGICAL RISK ASSESSOR, PUBLIC INFORMATION OFFICER AND/OR LAB QA/QC REVIEWER; AND UTILIZE THE APPROPRIATE PERSONNEL PER TASK; MPCA REVIEW TIME FRAMES WILL BE COORDINATED WITH APPROPRIATE EPA RPM.

DESCRIPTION:
THIS AGREEMENT MAY FUND THE PARTICIPATION OF THE RECIPIENT IN ACTIVITIES INCLUDING BUT NOT LIMITED TO THE REVIEW OF REMEDIAL INVESTIGATION AND FEASIBILITY STUDIES, PROPOSED PLANS, AND RECORDS OF DECISION AT SUPERFUND SITES FOR THE 5.7 MILLION RESIDENCE IN THE STATE OF MINNESOTA WHEN THE ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY (EPA) IS THE LEAD AGENCY FOR REMEDIAL ACTION. ACTIVITIES:
PLANNED ACTIVITIES FOR THE PERIOD OF APRIL 1, 2022 - MARCH 31, 2023 INCLUDE: REVIEW MONTHLY PROGRESS REPORTS; REVIEW 2021 ANNUAL REPORT; REVIEW INFORMATION AND RESULTS SUBMITTED BY BNSF REGARDING THE ISB TREATABILITY STUDY; REVIEW CORRESPONDENCE AND INFORMATION SUBMITTED BY BNSF REGARDING SAMPLING EVENTS, MANAGEMENT, AND OPERATION AND MAINTENANCE OF SITE; REVIEW AND ASSISTANCE WITH COMPLETING INSTITUTIONAL CONTROL(S) (INCLUDING DRAFTS) FOR THE SITE.

DESCRIPTION:THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT IS TO FUND ALL LNDIANA DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGEMENT (IDEM) REMEDIAL SUPPORT ACTIVITIES FOR THE SUPERFUND PROGRAM, OCCURRING AFTER COMPLETION OF THE SITE ASSESSMENT PROCESS. DESCRIPTION:THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT FULLY FUNDS THE OHIO ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY'S (EPA) FISCAL YEAR 2023 SITE ASSESSMENT PROGRAM IN THE AMOUNT OF $489,589.00. THE RECIPIENT'S PROGRAM WILL PERFORM SITE CHARACTERIZATION ACTIVITIES SUCH AS PRELIMINARY ASSESSMENTS AND SITE INSPECTION AT POTENTIAL OR CONFIRMED HAZARDOUS WASTE SITES.ACTIVITIES:ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDE THE FOLLOWING SITE ASSESSMENT AND RELATED ACTIONS. BASED ON ANNUAL WORKLOAD AND DISCUSSIONS WITH U.S. EPA REGION 5, THE OHIO EPA PLANS TO COMPLETE THE FOLLOWING SITE ASSESSMENT ACTIVITIES: 5 PRE-CERCLA SCREENINGS (PCS); 5 PRELIMINARY ASSESSMENTS (PAS); 4 SITE INSPECTIONS (SI); 2 EXPANDED SITE INSPECTION (ESI); AND 1 SITE REASSESSMENT (SR). THIS PLANNED WORK IS DYNAMIC, AS THE SCHEDULE AND LIST OF SITES MAY NEED TO BE MODIFIED BY EITHER U.S. EPA'S REGION 5 OR THE OHIO EPA'S PROGRAM DUE TO UNFORESEEN INFLUENCES. THE OHIO EPA WILL PROVIDE A CUMULATIVE COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT MODIFICATION AND A PROGRESS LOG TO THE U.S. EPA REGION 5 NATIONAL PRIORITIES LIST (NPL) COORDINATOR ON A QUARTERLY BASIS OR AS MODIFICATIONS ARE TENDERED FOR U.S. EPA REGION 5 APPROVAL, WHICHEVER IS SOONER.SUBRECIPIENT:NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.OUTCOMES:ANTICIPATED OUTCOMES AND EXPECTED DELIVERABLES WILL INCLUDE PROGRAM MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES SUCH AS: PROGRAM MANAGEMENT AND SUPERVISION; PLANNING AND WORKLOAD ASSESSMENTS TO DEVELOP THE LIST OF SITES AND TYPES OF SITE ASSESSMENTS TO BE COMPLETED ON AN ANNUAL BASIS; GRANT MANAGEMENT SUPPORT; GIS SUPPORT AND DEVELOPMENT; INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY SUPPORT; SITE ASSESSMENT PROGRAM DEVELOPMENT ACTIVITIES (SITE ASSESSMENT WORKGROUP); SAS SUPPORT; OCA SUPPORT; AND REPORTING; INCLUDING FOLLOWING UP ON ANY RECOMMENDATION LETTERS FROM A PREVIOUS GRANT CYCLE.  IN ADDITION TO OVERALL COORDINATION, OVERSIGHT AND SUPERVISION, MANAGEMENT UTILIZES STRATEGIC PLANNING TO DEVELOP AN ANNUAL SCHEDULE OF SITE WORK, SEASONAL PLANNING AND SCHEDULING TO COMPLETE ALL ASPECTS OF THE SITE ASSESSMENT ACTIVITIES - (E.G., GATHER HISTORIC SITE INFORMATION, RECONNAISSANCE, WORK PLAN, FIELD WORK AND REPORT WRITING) - FACTORING IN WEATHER AND SEASONAL EFFECTS TO COMPLETE THE PROJECTED WORKLOAD.

THE INTENDED BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE THE 11.7 MILLION RESIDENTS OF THE STATE OF OHIO AND THE PUBLIC AT LARGE.

THE NON-NPL REGION V STRATEGIC DIRECTION AND ENVIRONMENTAL OUTCOME IS TO NEGOTIATE REMEDIAL RI/FS ORDERS PRIOR TO COMPLETING A FULL HRS PACKAGE AND WITHOUT LISTING THE SITE ON THE NPL. THE OPTION EXISTS TO DEVELOP A FULL HRS PACKAGE BEFORE OR AFTER NEGOTIATIONS. IF NEGOTIATIONS ARE NOT SUCCESSFUL, THE OPTION EXISTS TO SWITCH TO THE NPL PROCESS WITH A FULL HRS PACKAGE DEVELOPED, PLACEMENT ON THE NPL AND THEN NEGOTIATE ORDERS WITH A POTENTIAL FOR FUND-LEAD ACTIVITIES AS APPROPRIATE.

DESCRIPTION:THE WISCONSIN DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES (WDNR) WILL CONDUCT SUPERFUND MULTISITE SUPPORT ACTIVITIES. THE ACTIVITIES HELP ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY (EPA) ACHIEVE PROGRAM GOALS AND PRIORITIES.  SPECIFICALLY, SUPERFUND MULTISITE SUPPORT ACTIVITIES HELP REGION 5 ACHIEVE ONE OF ITS LAND MEDIA PRIORITIES: CLEANUP SPILLS, FACILITATE THE RESTORATION OF CONTAMINATED PROPERTIES AND ACCELERATE THEIR RETURN TO PRODUCTIVE REUSE. DURING THE APRIL 1, 2023, TO MARCH 31, 2024 GRANT PERIOD WDNR WILL CONDUCT SUPPORT FOR: REMEDIAL INVESTIGATION/FEASIBILITY STUDY FOR 8 SITES; LONG-TERM RESPONSE ACTION FOR 36 SITES; AND REMOVAL FOR 1 SITE.

ACTIVITIES:WDNR SUPPORT FUNCTIONS INCLUDE PROVIDING INFORMATION ON THE SUPERFUND ACTIVITIES AT THE SITE TO CITIZENS, PUBLIC OFFICIALS, EPA, THE MEDIA, CONTRACTORS, AND ANY OTHER INTERESTED PARTIES ON REQUEST REVIEWING AND COMMENTING ON TECHNICAL ISSUES IN THE AREAS OF REMEDIATION, REDEVELOPMENT, ENDANGERED RESOURCES, FISHERIES, WATER RESOURCES MANAGEMENT, AND ANY OTHER AREAS RELATED TO SITE ACTIVITIES WHERE DNR HAS EXPERTISE/EXPERIENCE; ASSISTING EPA IN OBTAINING STATE OR LOCAL PERMITS RELATED TO THE SITE; REVIEWING AND COMMENTING ON PROGRESS REPORTS, SITE STATUS REPORTS, ETC., AS REQUESTED BY EPA; PARTICIPATING IN COMMUNITY RELATIONS ACTIVITIES AND COMMUNITY MEETINGS; PERFORMING FILE REVIEWS OR OTHER ACTIVITIES TO PROVIDE NECESSARY INFORMATION TO EPA; DEVELOPING AND EXECUTING SUPERFUND STATE CONTRACTS WITH EPA REGION 5 (RD, RA, AND LTRA STAGES); PROCURING AND ADMINISTERING SITE-SPECIFIC CONTRACTS, INCLUDING RECORDING CONTRACT PAYMENTS AND PROCESSING REMITTANCES PROVIDING SITE-SPECIFIC FISCAL DATA AS REQUESTED.SUBRECIPIENT:NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.OUTCOMES:WDNR INTENDS TO SUPPORT EPA IN SEVERAL ACTIVITIES RELATED TO IMPLEMENTATION OF THE SUPERFUND. WDNR PARTICIPATION IN THESE EFFORTS WILL ALSO ENSURE THAT ALL STATE SPECIFIC APPLICABLE, RELEVANT AND APPROPRIATE REQUIREMENTS (ARAR'S) ARE COMPLIED WITH. WDNR WILL ALSO PROVIDE FIELD OVERSIGHT ASSISTANCE SO THAT PROJECT CONSTRUCTION WORK IS COMPLETED IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE APPROVED PLANS AND SPECIFICATIONS. THE ACTIVITIES COVERED UNDER THIS AGREEMENT WILL DIRECTLY BENEFIT THE STATE OF WISCONSIN.

DESCRIPTION:THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT PROVIDES FUNDS TO SUPPORT WISCONSIN DNR SITE ASSESSMENT ACTIVITIES. SITE ASSESSMENT ACTIONS INCLUDE ACTIVITIES FROM SITE DISCOVERY, THROUGH EVALUATION AND SCORING UNTIL A SITE IS EITHER DESIGNATED AS NO FURTHER REMEDIAL ACTION PLANNED (NFRAP) OR MOVED FORWARD THROUGH EITHER STATE OR FEDERAL CLEANUP AUTHORITY. THIS INCLUDES TRADITIONAL SITE ASSESSMENT ACTIVITIES OF PRE-CERCLA SCREENINGS (PCS'S); PRELIMINARY ASSESSMENTS (PA'S); SITE INSPECTIONS (SI'S); EXPANDED SITE INVESTIGATIONS (ESI'S); AND HAZARD RANKING SYSTEM (HRS) SCORING PACKAGES. FOR SITES ALREADY IN THE SUPERFUND ENTERPRISE MANAGEMENT SYSTEM (SEMS), SITE REASSESSMENTS (SR) ARE USED TO DETERMINE APPROPRIATE FUTURE ACTIONS AT THE WISCONSIN DNR HAZARDOUS WASTE SITES, WHICH IS LISTED ON THE NATIONAL PRIORITIES LIST (NPL) OF THE NATIONAL OIL AND HAZARDOUS SUBSTANCES CONTINGENCY PLAN.

ACTIVITIES:SITE ASSESSMENT PROGRAM PLANNING AND MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES SUPPORT ACTIVITIES WHICH INCLUDE: 1) PROGRAM MANAGEMENT AND SUPERVISION, 2) PLANNING AND WORKLOAD ASSESSMENTS TO DEVELOP THE LIST OF SITES AND TYPES OF SITE ASSESSMENTS TO BE COMPLETED, 3) GRANT MANAGEMENT SUPPORT, 4) INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY SUPPORT, 5) SITE ASSESSMENT PROGRAM DEVELOPMENT ACTIVITIES, AND 6) REPORTING.  REMOVAL ACTIVITIES WDNR ANTICIPATES REFERRING 3 NEW SITES TO EPA DURING THE 1-YEAR GRANT PERIOD. WDNR WILL CONTINUE TO WORK WITH EPA'S REMOVAL PROGRAM TO PROVIDE ASSISTANCE WITH OUTREACH, REFERRAL PREPARATION, SITE VISITS, AND PREPARATION OF APPLICABLE OR RELEVANT AND APPROPRIATE REQUIREMENTS (ARARS). WDNR WILL ALSO REVIEW AND COMMENT ON ACTION MEMOS, WORK PLANS, AND SUMMARY REPORTS. WDNR WILL RESPOND TO ALL REQUESTS FOR INPUT IN A TIMELY MANNER.

SUBRECIPIENT:NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.OUTCOMES:THE ANTICIPATED DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES DATES ARE AS FOLLOW:
-	PRE-CERCLA SCREENING ASSESSMENT JUNE 2023 
-	PRELIMINARY ASSESSMENT PA DECEMBER 2023
-	SITE INSPECTION PLUS SI WORK PLAN JUNE 2023 - MARCH 2024
-	SITE REASSESSMENT JUNE 2023 - MARCH 2024
THE INTENDED RECIPIENTS ARE THE RESIDENTS OF WISCONSIN.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS AGREEMENT IS TO PROVIDE FUNDING TO THE ILLINOIS ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY (IEPA) TO SUPPORT ACTIVITIES AND MANAGEMENT ASSOCIATED WITH SITE ASSESSMENT ACTIVITIES. THIS AGREEMENT PROVIDES THE FIRST INCREMENTAL FUNDING TO IEPA IN THE AMOUNT OF $226,910 FOR REMEDIAL ACTIVITIES AS WELL AS $25,000 IN REMOVAL FUNDING. THE IEPA WILL CONDUCT PRE-CERCLIS SCREENING (PCS) ASSESSMENTS, PRELIMINARY ASSESSMENTS (PA), SITE INSPECTIONS (SI), EXPANDED SITE INVESTIGATIONS (ESI), HAZARD RANKING SYSTEM SCORING PACKAGE ASSISTANCE (HRA) FOR THE NATIONAL PRIORITIES LISTINGS (NPL), AND SITE RE-ASSESSMENTS (SR),  PROGRAM MANAGEMENT (PM) AND TIME-CRITICAL REMOVAL SUPPORT (TCS).

THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT (CA) PROVIDE FUNDS TO SUPPORT ACTIVITIES AND MANAGEMENT ASSOCIATED WITH THE INDIANA DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGEMENT (IDEM) SITE ASSESSMENT ACTIVITIES WHICH INCLUDE SITE DISCOVERY, THROUGH EVALUATION AND SCORING BASED ON SITE ASSESSMENT ACTIVITIES.  OTHER ACTIVITIES INCLUDE PRE-CERCLIS SCREENING (PCS), AND HAZARD RANKING SYSTEM (HRS) SCORING PACKAGES; SITE ASSESSMENT REASSESSMENTS (SR) AND TIME CRITICAL REMOVAL SUPPORT (TCS) ACTIVITIES. THIS IS CA IS PARTIALLY FUNDED IN THE AMOUNT OF $257,200.
THIS AGREEMENT FUNDS THE RECIPIENT'S PROGRAM TO PERFORM SITE CHARACTERIZATION ACTIVITIES SUCH AS PRELIMINARY ASSESSMENTS AND SITE INSPECTIONS AT POTENTIAL OR CONFIRMED HAZARDOUS WASTE SITES.

THESE EFFORTS WILL RESULT IN A MORE THOROUGH CLEANUP, WHICH WILL IN TURN PROVIDE A GREATER LEVEL OF PROTECTION TO HUMAN HEALTH AND THE ENVIRONMENT.  STATE INVOLVEMENT IN FEDERAL LEAD SITES RESULTS IN BETTER COMPLIANCE WITH STATE APPLICABLE REQUIREMENTS, FASTER CLEANUPS DUE TO BETTER COORDINATION BETWEEN STATE AND FEDERAL REGULATORY AGENCIES, AND GREATER CONSISTENCY BETWEEN CLEANUPS. THIS PROJECT SUPPORTS LAND PRESERVATION AND RESTORATION, CLEANUP AND RE-USE.

DESCRIPTION:
THE WISCONSIN DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES (WDNR) WILL CONDUCT SUPERFUND MULTISITE SUPPORT ACTIVITIES. THE ACTIVITIES WILL REVITALIZE LAND AND PREVENT CONTAMINATION, PROPERLY CLEAN UP CONTAMINATED SITES, AND RETURN THE LAND BACK TO COMMUNITIES.  DURING THE APRIL 1, 2022, TO MARCH 31, 2023 GRANT PERIOD WDNR WILL CONDUCT SUPPORT FOR: REMEDIAL INVESTIGATION/FEASIBILITY STUDY 6 SITES; REMEDIAL DESIGN 1 SITE; LONG-TERM RESPONSE ACTION 34 SITES.   

ACTIVITIES:
WDNR SUPPORT FUNCTIONS INCLUDE PROVIDING INFORMATION ON THE SUPERFUND ACTIVITIES AT THE SITE TO CITIZENS, PUBLIC OFFICIALS, EPA, THE MEDIA, CONTRACTORS, AND ANY OTHER INTERESTED PARTIES ON REQUEST REVIEWING AND COMMENTING ON TECHNICAL ISSUES IN THE AREAS OF REMEDIATION, REDEVELOPMENT, ENDANGERED RESOURCES, FISHERIES, WATER RESOURCES MANAGEMENT, AND ANY OTHER AREAS RELATED TO SITE ACTIVITIES WHERE DNR HAS EXPERTISE/EXPERIENCE; ASSISTING EPA IN OBTAINING STATE OR LOCAL PERMITS RELATED TO THE SITE; REVIEWING AND COMMENTING ON PROGRESS REPORTS, SITE STATUS REPORTS, ETC., AS REQUESTED BY EPA; PARTICIPATING IN COMMUNITY RELATIONS ACTIVITIES AND COMMUNITY MEETINGS; PERFORMING FILE REVIEWS OR OTHER ACTIVITIES TO PROVIDE NECESSARY INFORMATION TO EPA; DEVELOPING AND EXECUTING SUPERFUND STATE CONTRACTS WITH EPA REGION 5 (RD, RA, AND LTRA STAGES); PROCURING AND ADMINISTERING SITE-SPECIFIC CONTRACTS, INCLUDING RECORDING CONTRACT PAYMENTS AND PROCESSING REMITTANCES PROVIDING SITE-SPECIFIC FISCAL DATA AS REQUESTED.



OUTCOMES:
WDNR INTENDS TO SUPPORT EPA IN A NUMBER OF ACTIVITIES RELATED TO IMPLEMENTATION OF THE SUPERFUND.  WDNR PARTICIPATION IN THESE EFFORTS WILL ALSO ENSURE THAT ALL STATE SPECIFIC APPLICABLE, RELEVANT AND APPROPRIATE REQUIREMENTS (ARAR'S) ARE COMPLIED WITH.  WDNR WILL ALSO PROVIDE FIELD OVERSIGHT ASSISTANCE SO THAT PROJECT CONSTRUCTION WORK IS COMPLETED IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE APPROVED PLANS AND SPECIFICATIONS.  THE ACTIVITIES COVERED UNDER THIS AGREEMENT WILL DIRECTLY BENEFIT THE STATE OF WISCONSIN.

DESCRIPTION:THIS AGREEMENT FUNDS MULTNOMAH COUNTY HEALTH DEPARTMENT TO EXPAND THEIR FISH ADVISORY OUTREACH AND ENGAGEMENT PROGRAM. THIS INSTITUTIONAL CONTROL PROGRAM IS TO PROTECT FISH CONSUMERS FROM CONTAMINATES IN THE RESIDENT FISH IN THE WILLAMETTE RIVER BY PROVIDING EFFECTIVE RISK COMMUNICATION, ENCOURAGE AVOIDANCE TECHNIQUES, AND SUGGEST ALTERNATIVE MEANS TO CONTINUE CONSUMING FISH. ACTIVITIES:ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDE IN-LANGUAGE OUTREACH AND EDUCATION OF FISHERS AND MOMS ON THE DANGERS OF EATING RESIDENT FISH AND HEALTHIER ALTERNATIVES. SUBRECIPIENT:THE SUBAWARDS WILL CONDUCT CULTURALLY APPROPRIATE, IN-LANGUAGE EDUCATION AND OUTREACH TO COMMUNITIES AFFECTED BY THE FISH ADVISORY.  OUTCOMES:EXPECTED DELIVERABLES INCLUDE REPORTS ON ACTIVITY PROGRESS, COMPLETED TRAININGS, AND COMMUNITY OUTREACH ACTIVITIES. OUTCOMES INCLUDE REDUCING THE CONSUMPTION OF RESIDENT FISH AND A HEALTHIER FISH-CONSUMING POPULATION. THE INTENDED BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE THE FISHERS AND FISH-CONSUMING POPULATION ON THE WILLAMETTE RIVER.

DESCRIPTION:THIS AGREEMENT FUNDS THE PARTICIPATION OF THE SUQUAMISH INDIAN TRIBE OF THE PORT MADISON RESERVATION IN ACTIVITIES INCLUDING BUT NOT LIMITED TO THE REVIEW OF REMEDIAL INVESTIGATION AND FEASIBILITY STUDIES, PROPOSED PLANS, AND RECORDS OF DECISION AT THE BREMERTON GAS WORKS SUPERFUND SITE IN BREMERTON, WASHINGTON WHEN THE ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY (EPA) IS THE LEAD AGENCY FOR REMEDIAL ACTION. DESCRIPTION:THIS AGREEMENT FUNDS THE STATE OF ALASKA, DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL CONSERVATION (ADEC) PROGRAM TO PERFORM SITE CHARACTERIZATION ACTIVITIES SUCH AS PRELIMINARY ASSESSMENTS AND SITE INSPECTIONS AT POTENTIAL OR CONFIRMED HAZARDOUS WASTE SITES.ACTIVITIES:ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDE, BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO SITE ASSESSMENT TRAININGS, COMPLETED PRELIMINARY ASSESSMENTS, COMPLETED PRE-CERCLA (COMPREHENSIVE ENVIRONMENTAL RESPONSE, COMPENSATION, AND LIABILITY ACT) SCREENINGS, AND DISCOVERY OF NEW CONTAMINATED SITES.SUBRECIPIENT:NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.OUTCOMES:ANTICIPATED DELIVERABLES INCLUDE, BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO REPORTING ON PRELIMINARY ASSESSMENTS, PRE-CERLA SCREENINGS, AND SITE-DISCOVERY WORK.  ANTICIPATED OUTCOMES INCLUDE, BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO BETTER SKILLS FOR SITE DISCOVERY AND SITE ASSESSMENT, IDENTIFICATION OF SITES THAT WARRANT FURTHER INVESTIGATION, AND IDENTIFICATION OF SITES THAT NEED IMMEDIATE ACTION.  THE INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE THE RESIDENTS OF THE STATE OF ALASKA.

DESCRIPTION:THIS AGREEMENT FUNDS THE PARTICIPATION OF THE RECIPIENT IN ACTIVITIES INCLUDING BUT NOT LIMITED TO THE REVIEW OF REMEDIAL INVESTIGATION AND FEASIBILITY STUDIES, PROPOSED PLANS, AND RECORDS OF DECISION AT THE EAST WATERWAY OPERABLE UNIT AT THE HARBOR ISLAND SUPERFUND SITE WHERE THE ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY (EPA) IS THE LEAD AGENCY FOR REMEDIAL ACTION. ADDITIONALLY, THE TRIBE WILL COORDINATE WITH OTHER AGENCIES AND ATTEND SITE-RELATED MEETINGS.SUBRECIPIENT:NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.OUTCOMES:ANTICIPATED DELIVERABLES INCLUDE, BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO COMMENTS ON THE PROPOSED PLAN, RECORD OF DECISION, POST RECORD OF DECISION SAMPLING PLANS AND SAMPLING RESULTS, AND ENGINEERING EVALUATION AND COST ANALYSES AND PARTICIPATION IN SITE MEETINGS.  THE EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE MEANINGFUL PARTICIPATION OF THE TRIBE IN THE SUPERFUND CLEANUP PROCESS AND A CLEANER, HEALTHIER ENVIRONMENT IN THE TRIBE'S USUAL AND ACCUSTOMED AREAS. DESCRIPTION:
THE PURPOSE OF THIS AWARD IS TO PROVIDE FUNDING FOR THE NEZ PERCE TRIBE, THROUGH ITS WATER RESOURCES DIVISION, TO BE INVOLVED IN PHASE 1 OF THE ADMINISTRATIVE SETTLEMENT AGREEMENT AND ORDER ON CONSENT BETWEEN EPA, THE US FOREST SERVICE, AND PERPETUA RESOURCES AT THE STIBNITE MINE SITE. THE NEZ PERCE TRIBE HAVE TREATY-RESERVED RIGHTS TO HUNT, GATHER, PASTURE, AND TRAVEL AT THE SITE. HOWEVER, THE SITE HAS BEEN MINED FOR NEARLY A CENTURY AND IS HEAVILY CONTAMINATED WITH WASTE FROM THESE PAST MINING ACTIVITIES. THE GRANTEE WILL REVIEW AND COMMENT ON CERCLA DOCUMENTS RELATED TO THE TIME-CRITICAL REMOVAL ACTIONS, INCLUDING WORK PLANS AND DESIGN DOCUMENTS.
ACTIVITIES:
THE SCOPE OF WORK COVERS THE INVOLVEMENT OF THE NEZ PERCE TRIBE WATER RESOURCES DIVISION STAFF TO REVIEW AND COMMENT ON DOCUMENTS RELATED TO PHASE I OF THE ADMINISTRATIVE SETTLEMENT AGREEMENT AND ORDER ON CONSENT. THIS INCLUDES REVIEWING AND COMMENTING ON DOCUMENTS INCLUDING THE TIME-CRITICAL REMOVAL ACTION (TCRA) WORK PLANS, THE SITE CHARACTERIZATION REPORT WITH DATA GAP ANALYSIS, DESIGN PACKAGES, AND ADIT STUDIES; REVIEWING APPLICABLE AND RELEVANT LAWS AND REGULATIONS PERTAINING TO THE POLLUTION AT THE SITE; ATTENDING INTERDISCIPLINARY TEAM MEETINGS; ATTENDING MEETINGS WITH THE AGENCIES; AND A SITE VISIT FOR STAFF.
OUTCOMES:
THE TRIBE WILL SUBMIT SEMI-ANNUAL PROGRESS REPORTS AND WILL PROVIDE WRITTEN COMMENTS ON THE REPORTS AND DESIGN PACKAGES REVIEWED, AS APPROPRIATE. THE TRIBE WILL ALSO ATTEND MEETINGS WITH THE EPA AND USFS TO DISCUSS WORK PRODUCTS.
SUBRECIPIENT:
NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.

DELIVERABLES INCLUDE REPORTS ON ACTIVITY PROGRESS, COMPLETED TRAININGS, AND COMMUNITY OUTREACH ACTIVITIES.  OUTCOMES INCLUDE REDUCING THE CONSUMPTION OF RESIDENT FISH AND A HEALTHIER FISH-CONSUMING POPULATION.   SUBRECIPIENTS WILL CONDUCT OUTREACH AND TRAINING WITH THEIR TARGET AUDIENCE IN THEIR NATIVE LANGUAGE.

DESCRIPTION:THIS AGREEMENT MAY FUND THE PARTICIPATION OF THE RECIPIENT IN ACTIVITIES INCLUDING BUT NOT LIMITED TO THE REVIEW OF REMEDIAL INVESTIGATION AND FEASIBILITY STUDIES, PROPOSED PLANS, AND RECORDS OF DECISION AT THE TAR CREEK SUPERFUND SITE IN OKLAHOMA WHEN THE ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY (EPA) IS THE LEAD AGENCY FOR REMEDIAL ACTION. -TRIBAL PARTICIPATION, REVIEW, AND INPUT IN THE PLANNING AND DEVELOPMENT  OF REMEDIAL ACTIVITIES, INVESTIGATION, AND DOCUMENTATION
-PROVIDE TECHNICAL MANAGEMENT ASSISTANCE TO IMPACTED TRIBES
-SUPERFUND CAPACITY BUILDING
-COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT MANAGEMENT AND REPORTINGSUBRECIPIENT:NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.OUTCOMES:ANTICIPATED OUTCOMES, EXPECTED DELIVERABLES AND INTENDED BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE:
-TRIBE'S REVIEW, ANALYSIS, AND COMMENT ON EPA SITE DOCUMENTS AND DATA
-RETENTION OF TECHNICAL AND LEGAL SUPPORT CONTRACTOR TO FACILITATE TRIBE'S ACTIVITIES DESCRIBED ABOVE
-TRIBE'S REPORTING TO EPA DURING TERM OF THE COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT
THESE DELIVERABLES WIL BENEFIT THE RESIDENTS OF OKLAHOMA AND THE OTTOWA TRIBE.

DESCRIPTION:TRIBAL PROJECT MANAGEMENT: THE QUAPAW NATION WILL BE PERFORMING THE REMEDIAL RESPONSE ACTIVITY RELATED TO THE CLEANUP OF THE GENERIC CHAT REMOVAL RESTRICTED PROJECT; THE QUAPAW NATION ENVIRONMENTAL OFFICE (QNEO) WILL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR THE MANAGEMENT OF THE COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT (CA) GRANT AND FOR GENERAL PROJECT MANAGEMENT AND OVERSIGHT OF FIELD ACTIVITIES. ACCORDINGLY, THE QNEO, IN COORDINATION WITH THE EPA, WILL ENSURE THE QUALITY AND EFFECTIVENESS OF THE REMEDIAL ACTION.

SITE REMEDIATION: THIS TASK SHALL BE COMPLETED BY THE QNEO THROUGH ITS CONSTRUCTION DIVISION, QUAPAW SERVICES AUTHORITY (QSA), WITH THE POSSIBLE ASSISTANCE OF VARIOUS CONTRACTORS INCLUDING AN ENGINEERING SUPPORT CONTRACTOR AND A LABORATORY CONTRACTOR WHO WILL BE SELECTED, AS NECESSARY, BY THE QNEO UTILIZING THE NATION'S EXISTING PROCUREMENT PROCEDURES WHICH ARE CONSISTENT WITH THE PROCUREMENT REQUIREMENTS DESCRIBED IN THE CODE OF FEDERAL REGULATIONS (40 CFR PART 35 SUBPART O, SECTION 35.6550) FOR STATES AND TRIBES PROCURING SERVICES FUNDED BY EPA THROUGH THE SUPERFUND PROGRAM. THE QNEO WILL SEND REQUEST FOR PROPOSALS (RFP) TO SEVERAL QUALIFIED REMEDIATION RELATED CONTRACTORS AS NEEDED. BIDS WILL BE EVALUATED UTILIZING A QUALIFICATION-BASED GRADING SYSTEM.ACTIVITIES:PROJECT MANAGEMENT TASKS WILL INCLUDE: 
ON-SITE INSPECTION. THIS WILL INCLUDE HAVING A REPRESENTATIVE OF THE QNEO PERIODICALLY ON-SITE TO ENSURE THAT WORK COMPLIES WITH THE PLANS AND SPECIFICATIONS AS REVIEWED AND APPROVED. ON-SITE PERSONNEL REPRESENTING THE QNEO WILL BE QUALIFIED AND EXPERIENCED IN INSPECTION OF REMEDIATION PROJECTS AND WILL BE FAMILIAR ENOUGH WITH THE ENGINEERING PLANS AND ALL OTHER PROJECT RELATED DOCUMENTS (I.E. QA/QC PLANS, AND HEALTH AND SAFETY PLAN, SWPPP, FSP, SOPS, ETC.) TO ENSURE CONTRACTOR COMPLIANCE WITH THE REQUIREMENTS IN THESE DOCUMENTS. ON-SITE PERSONNEL SHALL KEEP DAILY LOGS AND TAKE PHOTOGRAPHS OF SITE ACTIVITY. DOCUMENT REVIEW. THIS WILL INCLUDE REVIEW OF SUBMITTALS FROM QSA, ENGINEERING CONSULTANT IF APPLICABLE, AND ANALYTICAL LAB (PROGRESS REPORTS, ENGINEERING DRAWINGS, WORK MEASUREMENT, PAY REQUESTS, LAB RESULTS, INSPECTION REPORTS, PHOTOGRAPHS, ETC.).  MEETINGS. QNEO STAFF WILL PARTICIPATE IN PROJECT RELATED MEETINGS INCLUDING PERIODIC DAILY TAILGATE MEETINGS, PROGRESS MEETINGS, SAFETY MEETINGS, CONSULTATION MEETINGS WITH DEQ AND EPA, AND OTHER MEETINGS AS ISSUES ARISE. THIS MAY INCLUDE UTILIZATION OF THE ENGINEERING SUPPORT CONTRACTOR TO REPRESENT THE QNEO WHEN APPROPRIATE STAFF PERSONS ARE UNABLE TO ATTEND SOME MEETINGS. COORDINATION/CONSULTATION WITH ODEQ AND EPA. THIS WILL INCLUDE ONGOING COMMUNICATIONS AND MEETINGS; AND GENERATING THE REQUIRED REPORTS. PUBLIC OUTREACH. THIS WILL INCLUDE PUBLIC MEETINGS, NEWSLETTER ARTICLES, INFORMATION AVAILABILITY OUTREACH EFFORTS, AND REPORTING TO THE TRIBAL BUSINESS COMMITTEE. THE ODEQ AND EPA WILL BE NOTIFIED OF ANY SCHEDULE PUBLIC MEETINGS OR OUTREACH EFFORTS. PROJECT ADMINISTRATION. THIS WILL INCLUDE, BUT NOT LIMITED TO, BUDGET TRACKING, RECORDS/DOCUMENT MANAGEMENT AND STORAGE, REVIEW OF QSA INVOICES, AND COMMUNICATIONS WITH ODEQ AND EPA PROJECT ADMINISTRATIVE STAFF.

SITE REMEDIATION TASKS WILL INCLUDE:
1 GRANT AWARD 
2 DEVELOP SITE-SPECIFIC PLANS (TRANSPORTATION PLAN, STORM WATER POLLUTION PREVENTION PLAN, ETC.)
3 PRE-CONSTRUCTION MEETING
4 MOBILIZATION AND SITE PREPARATION 
5 SOURCE MATERIAL REMOVAL
6 POST-CONSTRUCTION MEETING/FINAL WALKTHROUGH
7 DECONTAMINATION/DEMOBILIZATION
8 DEVELOP AND FINALIZE REMEDIAL ACTION REPORT 
9 FINALIZE GRANT CLOSE-OUT
SUBRECIPIENT:NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.OUTCOMES:PROJECT DELIVERABLES WILL BE BOTH ADMINISTRATIVE AND TECHNICAL IN NATURE. THE ADMINISTRATIVE/GRANT DELIVERABLES WILL INCLUDE 1) QUARTERLY REPORTING TO THE EPA-DESIGNATED PROJECT OFFICER ON THE PROGRESS MADE TOWARD INDIVIDUAL WORK PLAN TASKS ALONG WITH FINANCIAL UPDATES, 2) A FINAL REPORT DOCUMENTING THE SUCCESSFUL COMPLETION OF ALL WORK PLAN TASKS, AND 3)

DESCRIPTION:THIS AGREEMENT MAY FUND THE PARTICIPATION OF THE NEW MEXICO ENVIRONMENTAL DEPARTMENT (NMED) RECIPIENT IN ACTIVITIES TO CONDUCT ADMINISTRATIVE ASSISTANCE, MANAGEMENT ASSISTANCE, TECHNICAL EVALUATION AND SUBSTANTIAL COMMUNITY OUTREACH ENGAGEMENT ACTIVITIES AT THE BONITA PEAK MINING DISTRICT (BPMD) SUPERFUND SITE AS PART OF THE GOLD KING MINE RELEASE SETTLEMENT AGREEMENT (GKM), WHICH IS LISTED ON THE NATIONAL PRIORITIES LIST (NPL) OF THE NATIONAL OIL AND HAZARDOUS SUBSTANCES CONTINGENCY PLAN. THESE ACTIVITIES MAY INCLUDE BUT NOT BE LIMITED TO THE REVIEW OF REMEDIAL INVESTIGATION AND FEASIBILITY STUDIES, PROPOSED PLANS, AND RECORDS OF DECISION WHEN THE ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY (EPA) IS THE LEAD AGENCY FOR REMEDIAL ACTION. THIS CAN ALSO INCLUDE REVIEW OF INFORMATION, ATTENDING SITE-RELATED MEETINGS AND PARTICIPATING IN FIVE-YEAR REVIEWS.ACTIVITIES:ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDE THE FOLLOWING SUPPORT AGENCY ACTIVITIES:
NEW MEXICO ENVIRONMENTAL DEPARTMENT (NMED) STAFF WILL PROVIDE MANAGEMENT ASSISTANCE TO THE ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY (EPA) BY PROVIDING TO THE PUBLIC, COMMUNITY INVOLVEMENT OUTREACH AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, DETAILED TECHNICAL REVIEW OF REMEDIAL DESIGNS, EVALUATIONS OF REMEDY PERFORMANCE AND FIELD RECONNAISSANCE.
- PROVIDE EPA REGION 6 WITH INFORMATION AND UNDERSTANDING OF THE IMMEDIATE AND LONG-TERM OUTCOME OF ANY REMEDIAL OR REMOVAL RESPONSE ACTIONS TAKING PLACE AT THE BONITA PEAK MINING DISTRICT (BPMD) THAT COULD RESULT IN BENEFIT TO THE CITIZENS OF NEW MEXICO OR THE LACK THEREOF IN PROVIDING LONG-TERM BENEFIT AND THE PROTECTION OF DOWNSTREAM USERS AND CITIZENS.
- SUBSTANTIAL AND MEANINGFUL ENGAGEMENT IS NECESSARY FOR NEW MEXICO'S UNDERSTANDING OF THE REMEDIAL ACTIONS BEING SELECTED AND IMPLEMENTED AT THE SITE. MANY TIMES, THIS INFORMATION IS VERY TECHNICAL AND NEEDS TO BE PROVIDED ACCURATELY AND CONCISELY, BY SOMEONE WITH ON-SITE KNOWLEDGE OF THE BPMD SITE TO THE PUBLIC AND TO EPA.
- PROVIDE TECHNICAL EXPERTISE AND COMMUNITY OUTREACH TO SUPPLEMENT AND ASSIST THE NEW MEXICO CHIEF SCIENCE OFFICER WITH EMERGENCY RESPONSE ACTIONS NECESSITATED BY ANY FUTURE CONTROLLED OR UNCONTROLLED DISCHARGES FROM THE BPMD THAT MAY RESULT IN IMPACTED DISCHARGES REACHING NEW MEXICO.
SUBRECIPIENT:NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.OUTCOMES:ANTICIPATED OUTCOMES, EXPECTED DELIVERABLES AND INTENDED BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE:
- TWICE YEARLY FIRSTHAND OBSERVATIONS OF PAST IMPLEMENTED REMEDIAL ACTIONS AND ANY CURRENT REMEDIES BEING CONSTRUCTED, INCLUDING BUT NOT LIMITED TO OBSERVATION OF WATER COLLECTION AND CONTAINMENT STRUCTURES, WATER TREATMENT FACILITIES, EDIT DISCHARGES, OR ANY OTHER REMEDIES SELECTED FOR IMPLEMENTATION AT THE BONITA PEAK MINING DISTRICT (BPMD).
-CONTINUOUS NEW MEXICO ENVIRONMENTAL DEPARTMENT (NMED) INVOLVEMENT IN REVIEWING SUPERFUND DOCUMENTS AS THEY ARE MADE AVAILABLE FOR PUBLIC REVIEW AND COMMENT.
-TRACK THE REPORTING OF SPILLS AND RELEASES RELATED TO BPMD FOR INFORMATION SHARING WITH THE LOCAL COMMUNITIES. THIS WILL INCLUDE EVALUATING THE TYPE OF SPILL OR RELEASE AND WHAT CORRECTIVE ACTIONS ARE TAKING PLACE TO PROTECT HUMAN HEALTH AND ENVIRONMENT IN NEW MEXICO. CURRENTLY, EPA REGION 8 IS DRAFTING A NEW MEXICO SPECIFIC COMMUNITY INVOLVEMENT PLAN (CIP), WHICH WILL INCLUDE A SECTION ON S, NOTIFICATIONS AND SPILL REPORTING. ONCE RECEIVED, NMED WILL REVIEW THE CIP FOR THOROUGHNESS AND APPROPRIATENESS, AND WILL WORK WITH EPA TO DEVELOP A COMPREHENSIVE PLAN FOR THE STATE OF NEW MEXICO
- PROVIDE TECHNICAL EXPERTISE FOR COMMUNITY OUTREACH TO ESTABLISH COMMUNICATION AND COORDINATION FOR ALL CONCERNED NEW MEXICO CITIZENS AND POTENTIALLY EFFECTED LOCAL GOVERNMENTS.
- ESTABLISH A LOCAL INFORMATION REPOSITORY AND PROVIDE THE TECHNICAL EXPERTISE TO THE LOCAL COMMUNITY, INVOLVED STAKEHOLDERS AND CITIZENS. INCLUDING BUT NOT LIMITED TO PROVIDING INFORMATION ON ALL RESPONSE ACTIONS TAKING PLACE IN CONJUNCTION WITH THE BPMD SUPERFUND SI

DESCRIPTION:THIS AGREEMENT FUNDS THE RECIPIENT'S PROGRAM TO CONDUCT REMEDIAL ACTION ACTIVITIES AT THE UNRESTRICTED SITES WITHIN THE TAR CREEK OPERABLE UNIT 4 SUPERFUND SITE, WHICH IS LISTED ON THE NATIONAL PRIORITIES LIST (NPL) OF THE NATIONAL OIL AND HAZARDOUS SUBSTANCES CONTINGENCY PLAN. ACTIVITIES:THE ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDE THE FOLLOWING SITE-SPECIFIC ACTIONS:
THE OBJECTIVE IS TO REDUCE EXPOSURE AND MEET THE REMEDIAL ACTION OBJECTIVES (RAO)S ON UNRESTRICTED PROPERTIES BY REMEDIATING CONTAMINATED SOURCE MATERIAL (CHAT PILES/BASES, OTHER MINE AND MILL WASTES AND SMELTER WASTE) AND TRANSITION ZONE SOILS, AS ASSOCIATED WITH OPERABLE UNIT (OU) 4 REMEDIAL ACTION.SUBRECIPIENT:NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.OUTCOMES:PROJECT DELIVERABLES WILL BE BOTH ADMINISTRATIVE AND TECHNICAL IN NATURE. TECHNICAL AND ADMINISTRATIVE DELIVERABLES WILL INCLUDE:
- DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY (ODEQ WILL SUBMIT QUARTERLY REPORTS TO THE ENVIRONMENT PROTECTION AGENCY (EPA) - DESIGNATED PROJECT OFFICER AND REMEDIAL PROJECT MANAGER ON THE PROGRESS MADE TOWARD THE INDIVIDUAL WORK PLAN TASKS ALONG WITH THE FINANCIAL STATUS REPORTS. THIS WILL BE SUBMITTED WITHIN 60 DAYS OF THE END OF EACH FEDERAL
QUARTER.
- ODEQ WILL REVIEW AND APPROVE SITE SPECIFIC PROJECT PLANS SUBMITTED BY THE CONTRACTOR/CONSULTANT INCLUDING QUALITY ASSURANCE PROJECT PLAN (QAPP).
- ODEQ WILL REVIEW, APPROVE, AND PROCESS PAYMENT OF PROJECT INVOICES.
- ODEQ WILL TRAVEL TO THE PROJECT SITE AND ATTEND ANY SITE MEETINGS CONCERNING THE PROJECT.
- ODEQ WILL SUBMIT ALL OTHER CERTIFICATIONS AND FORMS REQUIRED TO SUCCESSFULLY ADMINISTER AND CLOSE-OUT THIS EPA COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT.
- ODEQ WILL UPDATE THE TAR CREEK SITEWIDE COMMUNITY INVOLVEMENT PLAN (CIP) IF NECESSARY. ANY CHANGES TO THE SITE-WIDE CIP WILL BE SUBMITTED TO EPA FOR REVIEW.
- ODEQ WILL CONDUCT WEEKLY CALLS WITH THE PROJECT CONTRACTOR AND CONSULTANT TO REPORT ON ISSUES AND PROGRESS.
- ODEQ WILL SCHEDULE A PRE-FINAL AND FINAL WALKTHROUGHS WITH THE LANDOWNERS AND CONTRACTOR PRIOR TO CLOSE-OUT. EPA WILL BE INVITED TO PARTICIPATE IN THE WALK-THROUGH.
- ODEQ WILL SUBMIT A REMEDIAL ACTION REPORT (RAR) DRAFTED BY THE CONTRACTOR AND APPROVED BY DEQ. THE RAR WILL DOCUMENT THE SUCCESSFUL COMPLETION OF ALL WORK PLAN AND REMEDIAL TASKS. THE RAR WILL SUMMARIZE WORK OUTPUTS AND OUTCOMES AND WILL BE
COMPLETED BY THE CONTRACTOR WITHIN 120 DAYS OF THE COMPLETION OF THE PROJECT. THIS 120 DAY SUBMITTAL INCLUDES 30 DAYS FOR DRAFT AND SUBMISSION BY THE CONTRACTOR TO DEQ, 30 DAYS FOR DEQ REVIEW AND APPROVAL, 30 DAYS FOR EPA REVIEW, AND 30 DAYS FOR DEQ TO
ADDRESS ANY COMMENTS PROVIDED BY EPA.
- ODEQ WILL FILE NOTICE OF REMEDIATION, WHICH MAY OR MAY NOT INCLUDE PROPERTY RESTRICTIONS, IN THE DEED RECORDS OF THE OTTAWA COUNTY COURTHOUSE.
- ODEQ WILL OVERSEE THE CONTRACTOR AND IS ULTIMATELY RESPONSIBLE FOR THE OVERALL SUCCESS OF THE PROJECT AND THE QUALITY OF THE WORK PRODUCT.

DESCRIPTION:THIS AGREEMENT FUNDS THE RECIPIENT'S PROGRAM TO CONDUCT REMEDIAL ACTION AT THE TAR CREEK OPERABLE UNIT 4 HAZARDOUS WASTE SITE, WHICH IS LISTED ON THE NATIONAL PRIORITIES LIST (NPL) OF THE NATIONAL OIL AND HAZARDOUS SUBSTANCES CONTINGENCY PLAN.ACTIVITIES:THE ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDE THE FOLLOWING SITE-SPECIFIC ACTIONS: 
TASK 1 METHOD: THE TRIBAL PROJECT MANAGEMENT TASKS WILL BE ACCOMPLISHED BY UTILIZING QNEO STAFF. ALL TIME AND EFFORT EXPENDED IN COMPLETING THESE TASKS SHALL BE REPORTED IN THE QUARTERLY REPORTS TO ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY (EPA).
TASK 2: SITE REMEDIATION: 
THIS PROPOSED REMEDIAL RESPONSE WILL ONLY ADDRESS SOURCE MATERIAL (UNMARKETABLE). THIS REMEDIAL ACTION WILL ALSO CONSIDER THE RECOMMENDATIONS OF THE EPA'S OPTIMIZATION REPORT. THE CONTAMINANTS OF CONCERN (COCS) AT THE SITE ARE LEAD, ZINC, AND CADMIUM. REMEDIAL PROJECT GOALS (PRGS) FOR LEAD, ZINC, AND CADMIUM ARE 500 MG/KG, 1100 MG/KG, AND 10 MG/KG, RESPECTIVELY, THOUGH AS AN INTERIM MEASURE PROJECT, THIS SITE WILL NOT BE REMEDIATED TO PRGS.
BEFORE COMMENCING REMEDIAL ACTION AT THE SITE, THE QUAPAW NATION SHALL PREPARE AND SUBMIT THE FOLLOWING PROJECT PLANS TO EPA FOR REVIEW AND APPROVAL: STORM WATER POLLUTION PREVENTION PLAN (SWPPP), AND TRANSPORTATION PLAN (TP).SUBRECIPIENT:NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.OUTCOMES:ANTICIPATED OUTCOMES, EXPECTED DELIVERABLES AND INTENDED BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE: INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: QUAPAW NATION ENVIRONMENTAL OFFICE AND THE CITIZENS OF THE QUAPAW NATION.
SCHEDULE OF DELIVERABLES
PROJECT DELIVERABLES WILL BE BOTH ADMINISTRATIVE AND TECHNICAL IN NATURE. THE ADMINISTRATIVE/GRANT DELIVERABLES WILL INCLUDE 1) QUARTERLY REPORTING TO THE EPA-DESIGNATED PROJECT OFFICER ON THE PROGRESS MADE TOWARD INDIVIDUAL WORK PLAN TASKS ALONG WITH FINANCIAL UPDATES, 2) A FINAL REPORT DOCUMENTING THE SUCCESSFUL COMPLETION OF ALL WORK PLAN TASKS, AND 3) ALL OTHER CERTIFICATIONS AND GRANT FORMS TYPICALLY REQUIRED TO SUCCESSFULLY ADMINISTER AND CLOSE-OUT AN EPA GRANT. THE TECHNICAL/REMEDIATION DELIVERABLES WILL INCLUDE: 1) PERIODIC CONFERENCE CALLS AND MEETINGS WITH THE EPA-DESIGNATED REMEDIAL PROJECT MANAGER (RPM) TO REPORT ON THE PROGRESS MADE IN PLANNING, IMPLEMENTING, AND FINISHING THE PROPOSED REMEDIAL PROJECT, 2) A FINAL WALK THROUGH WITH EPA STAFF AND TRIBAL REPRESENTATIVES PRIOR TO PROJECT CLOSE-OUT, AND 3) A REMEDIAL ACTION REPORT UPON PROJECT CLOSE-OUT.

DESCRIPTION:THIS AGREEMENT FUNDS THE RECIPIENT'S PROGRAM TO PERFORM SITE CHARACTERIZATION ACTIVITIES SUCH AS PRELIMINARY ASSESSMENTS AND SITE INSPECTION AT POTENTIAL OR CONFIRMED HAZARDOUS WASTE SITES.ACTIVITIES:ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDE THE FOLLOWING SITE ASSESSMENT RELATED ACTIONS: 
TCEQ WILL PREPARE:
PRE-CERCLA SCREENING ASSESSMENTS (PCS)
PRELIMINARY ASSESSMENTS (PA)
SITE INSPECTIONS (SI), 
EXPANDED SITE INSPECTIONS (ESI)
HAZARD RANKING SYSTEM (HRS) DOCUMENTATION RECORDS, 
OR EQUIVALENT PROJECTS, IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE PROPOSED GRANT WITH THE U.S. ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY (EPA). EQUIVALENT PROJECTS MAY
INCLUDE DETERMINING THE ELIGIBILITY OF PROJECTS FOR THE PA/SI PROGRAM AND/OR RE-ASSESSMENTS AS REQUESTED BY THE EPA. PRIOR TO BEGINNING ANY FIELD WORK, THE TCEQ AND EPA WILL AGREE ON POTENTIAL SITES TO BE INVESTIGATED. THESE ASSESSMENTS AND INSPECTIONS WILL INCLUDE DIFFERENT TYPES OF SITES INCLUDING, BUT NOT LIMITED TO, CHEMICAL PROCESSORS, OTHER INDUSTRIAL FACILITIES, WASTE DISPOSAL SITES, AND UNIDENTIFIED GROUNDWATER PLUMES.
SUBRECIPIENT:NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.OUTCOMES:ANTICIPATED OUTCOMES, EXPECTED DELIVERABLES AND INTENDED BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE:
INTENDED BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE TCEQ AND THE RESIDENTS OF THE STATE OF TEXAS.
ANTICIPATED OUTCOMES, EXPECTED DELIVERABLES AND INTENDED BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE FULL PRE-CERCLA SCREENING ASSESSMENTS, PRELIMINARY ASSESSMENTS, SITE INSPECTIONS, EXPANDED SITE INSPECTIONS, AND HAZARD RANKING SYSTEM DOCUMENTATION RECORDS. A FINAL REPORT WILL BE PREPARED FOLLOWING THE SITE VISITS AND COMPLETION OF ANALYTICAL WORK TO REPORT SIGNIFICANT FINDINGS FOR EACH SITE, INCLUDING:  A SITE DESCRIPTION, OPERATING HISTORY AND NATURE OF WASTE HANDLING AT THE SITE, DISCUSSION OF WASTE SOURCES AND PATHWAY CHARACTERISTICS, AND IDENTIFICATION AND DESCRIPTION OF POTENTIAL HUMAN AND ENVIRONMENTAL RECEPTORS. TCEQ WILL ALSO PROVIDE QUARTERLY REPORTS.

DESCRIPTION:THIS AGREEMENT FUNDS THE RECIPIENT'S PROGRAM TO CONDUCT REMEDIAL ACTION AT THE EAGLE PICHER HAZARDOUS WASTE SITE, WHICH IS LISTED ON THE NATIONAL PRIORITIES LIST (NPL) OF THE NATIONAL OIL AND HAZARDOUS SUBSTANCES CONTINGENCY PLAN.ACTIVITIES:THE ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDE THE FOLLOWING SITE-SPECIFIC ACTIONS; TO PERFORM THE SOIL AND CONSTRUCTION DEBRIS REMOVAL COMPONENT OF THE OU 1 REMEDIAL STRATEGY. THE WORK WILL BE CONDUCTED IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE ROD (2014). NMED WILL PROVIDE PROJECT MANAGEMENT AND CONTRACTOR OVERSIGHT WHILE UTILIZING A PROFESSIONAL SERVICES CONTRACTOR (CONTRACTOR) TO IMPLEMENT THE REMOVAL WORK AT THE SITE.SUBRECIPIENT:NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.OUTCOMES:ANTICIPATED OUTCOMES, EXPECTED DELIVERABLES AND INTENDED BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE; NMED WILL PROVIDE EPA WITH FINANCIAL STATUS AND PROJECT PROGRESS REPORTS. THESE REPORTS WILL DETAIL EXPENDITURES AND DISCUSS SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES CONDUCTED IN PERFORMANCE OF THE RA AT THE SITE. THE SCHEDULE FOR SUBMITTAL OF THESE REPORTS WILL BE SPECIFIED BY EPA. TECHNICAL DELIVERABLES INCLUDE BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO HEALTH AND SAFETY PLANS, CONSTRUCTION QUALITY
ASSURANCE PROJECT PLANS, SURVEYING REPORTS, DAMAGE PREVENTION PLANS, DUST CONTROL PLANS, TRAFFIC ROUTING PLANS, MONTHLY STATUS REPORTS, INSPECTION REPORTS, PERMITS, AND A FINAL REMEDIAL ACTION REPORT. THESE REPORTS WILL BE PREPARED BY NMED'S CONTRACTOR. NMED AND EPA WILL PROVIDE COMMENTS ON DRAFT DELIVERABLES FOR INCORPORATION PRIOR TO FINALIZATION. THE CITIZENS OF NEW MEXICO ARE THE INTENDED BENEFICIARIES.

DESCRIPTION:THIS AGREEMENT FUNDS THE RECIPIENT'S PROGRAM TO CONDUCT THE REMEDIAL ACTION AT THE EAGLE PICHER CAREFREE BATTERY HAZARDOUS WASTE SITE, WHICH IS LISTED ON THE NATIONAL PRIORITIES LIST (NPL) OF THE NATIONAL OIL AND HAZARDOUS SUBSTANCES CONTINGENCY PLAN.ACTIVITIES:THE ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDE THE FOLLOWING SITE-SPECIFIC ACTIONS: 
- PUMP AND TREAT SYSTEM CONSTRUCTION: EXTRACTION WELLS TO CAPTURE CONTAMINATED GROUNDWATER, A CENTRAL ADVANCED OXIDATION PROCESS (AOP) TREATMENT FACILITY TO TREAT THE CONTAMINATED GROUNDWATER, AND INJECTION WELLS LOCATED ON THE EAGLE PICHER PROPERTY TO DISPOSE OF THE TREATED GROUNDWATER.
- IMPLEMENTING THE PUMP AND TREAT SYSTEM IN TWO PHASES: 1) PHASE I, WHICH INVOLVES CAPTURING GROUNDWATER IN THE HIGHLY CONTAMINATED AREAS OF THE PLUME, FORMS THE BASIS OF THIS WORK PLAN; AND, 2) PHASE II, WHICH INVOLVES CAPTURING CONTAMINATED GROUNDWATER AT THE LEADING EDGE OF THE PLUME, IS DEPENDENT ON INFORMATION GATHERED DURING PHASE I.
SUBRECIPIENT:NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.OUTCOMES:ANTICIPATED OUTCOMES, EXPECTED DELIVERABLES AND INTENDED BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE:
NMED WILL PROVIDE EPA WITH FINANCIAL STATUS AND PROJECT PROGRESS REPORTS. THESE REPORTS WILL DETAIL EXPENDITURES AND DISCUSS SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES CONDUCTED IN PERFORMANCE OF THE RA AT THE SITE. THE SCHEDULE FOR SUBMITTAL OF THESE REPORTS WILL BE SPECIFIED BY EPA.
TECHNICAL DELIVERABLES INCLUDE BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO HEALTH AND SAFETY PLANS, CONSTRUCTION QUALITY ASSURANCE PROJECT PLANS, SAMPLING PLAN AND OPERATIONS AND MAINTENANCE PLAN, MONTHLY REPORTING, INSPECTION REPORTS, INTERIM REMEDIAL ACTION COMPLETION REPORTS, GROUNDWATER MONITORING REPORTS, FY24 AND FY25 ANNUAL COMPREHENSIVE GROUNDWATER MONITORING REPORTS, AND PERMITS. THESE REPORTS WILL BE PREPARED BY NMED'S CONTRACTOR. NMED AND EPA WILL PROVIDE COMMENTS ON DRAFT DELIVERABLES FOR INCORPORATION PRIOR TO FINALIZATION.

DESCRIPTION:THIS AGREEMENT FUNDS THE RECIPIENT'S PROGRAM TO CONDUCT REMEDIAL ACTION AT THE MCGAFFEY AND MAIN HAZARDOUS WASTE SITE, WHICH IS LISTED ON THE NATIONAL PRIORITIES LIST (NPL) OF THE NATIONAL OIL AND HAZARDOUS SUBSTANCES CONTINGENCY PLAN.ACTIVITIES:THE ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDE THE FOLLOWING SITE-SPECIFIC ACTIONS INCLUDE: 

MCGAFFEY AND MAIN RA (SAGW PANDT) ACTIVITIES SUPPORT EPA AND NMED'S GOAL TO PRESERVE AND RESTORE LAND BY USING INNOVATIVE WASTE MANAGEMENT PRACTICES AND CLEANING UP CONTAMINATED PROPERTIES TO REDUCE RISKS POSED BY RELEASES OF HARMFUL SUBSTANCES. MCGAFFEY AND MAIN RA ACTIVITIES WILL ALSO CONTRIBUTE TO CONTROLLING RISKS TO HUMAN HEALTH AND THE ENVIRONMENT BY ENSURING SELECTED REMEDIES ADDRESS AND MITIGATE THE IMPACT OF ACCIDENTAL OR INTENTIONAL RELEASES AND CLEAN UP AND RESTORE CONTAMINATED SITES OR PROPERTIES TO APPROPRIATE CLEAN UP LEVELS. NMED STAFF WILL EVALUATE PROPOSED AND IMPLEMENTED REMEDIES TO ENSURE THAT CONTAMINATED SITES DO NOT POSE THREATS TO HUMAN HEALTH AND THE ENVIRONMENT
AND ALLOW FOR THE REUSE OF THE LAND. THIS AGREEMENT ENABLES NMED TO PARTICIPATE AND LEAD THE SAGW CONSTRUCTION AND OPERATION TO ENSURE THAT HUMAN EXPOSURE TO SUPERFUND HAZARDOUS WASTE SITES ARE MINIMIZED THROUGH THE CLEANUP OF CONTAMINATED GROUNDWATER AT THE SITE SOURCE AREA.SUBRECIPIENT:NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.OUTCOMES:ANTICIPATED OUTCOMES, EXPECTED DELIVERABLES AND INTENDED BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE: 

NMED WILL PROVIDE EPA WITH FINANCIAL STATUS AND PROJECT PROGRESS REPORTS. THESE REPORTS WILL DETAIL EXPENDITURES AND DISCUSS THE SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES CONDUCTED IN THE PERFORMANCE OF RA AT THE SITE. THE SCHEDULE FOR SUBMITTAL OF THESE REPORTS WILL BE SPECIFIED BY EPA. TECHNICAL DELIVERABLES INCLUDE BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO HEALTH AND SAFETY PLANS, CONSTRUCTION QUALITY
ASSURANCE PROJECT PLANS, SAMPLING PLAN AND OPERATIONS AND MAINTENANCE PLAN, MONTHLY REPORTING, INSPECTION REPORTS, INTERIM REMEDIAL ACTION COMPLETION REPORTS, SEMIANNUAL GROUNDWATER
MONITORING REPORTS, FY24 AND FY25 ANNUAL COMPREHENSIVE GROUNDWATER MONITORING REPORTS, AND CITY OF ROSWELL WASTEWATER DISCHARGE PERMIT. THESE REPORTS WILL GENERALLY BE PREPARED BY NMED'S CONTRACTOR; GROUNDWATER MONITORING REPORTS MAY OR MAY NOT BE PREPARED BY NMED.  NMED AND EPA WILL PROVIDE COMMENTS ON DRAFT DELIVERABLES FOR INCORPORATION PRIOR TO
FINALIZATION.

DESCRIPTION:THIS AGREEMENT FUNDS THE RECIPIENT'S PROGRAM TO PERFORM SHORT-TERM RESPONSE ACTIVITIES TO STABILIZE OR CLEAN UP HAZARDOUS WASTES AT AN INCIDENT OR SITE THAT POSES A THREAT TO PUBLIC HEALTH OR WELFARE. THE BENEFITED PARTIES WILL BE THE 11.7 MILLION RESIDENCE OF THE STATE OF OHIO.

THIS AGREEMENT MAY FUND THE PARTICIPATION OF THE RECIPIENT IN ACTIVITIES INCLUDING BUT NOT LIMITED TO THE REVIEW OF REMEDIAL INVESTIGATION AND FEASIBILITY STUDIES, PROPOSED PLANS, AND RECORDS OF DECISION AT SUPERFUND SITES IN WISCONSIN WHEN THE ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY (EPA) IS THE LEAD AGENCY FOR REMEDIAL ACTION.  THIS CAN ALSO INCLUDE REVIEW OF INFORMATION, ATTENDING SITE-RELATED MEETINGS AND PARTICIPATING IN FIVE-YEAR REVIEWS. THE PURPOSE OF CONDUCTING 5-YEAR REVIEW IS TO ENSURE THAT THE SITE BEING EVALUATED IS SAFE AND TO ENSURE THAT THE REMEDY CONTINUES TO PROTECT PEOPLE AND THE ENVIRONMENT.  THE 5-YEAR REVIEW PROCESS INCLUDES COMMUNITY NOTIFICATION AND INVOLVEMENT, DOCUMENT REVIEW, SITE INSPECTION, AND ADMINISTRATIVE COMPONENTS.  WISCONSIN DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES WILL SUBMIT A DETAILED REPORT TO EPA REGION 5.

DESCRIPTION:THIS ACTION APPROVES AN AWARD IN THE AMOUNT OF $139,828 TO THE TENNESSEE DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENT AND CONSERVATION. THE PURPOSE OF THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT IS TO PROVIDE FUNDS TO THE RECIPIENT TO PERFORM SITE CHARACTERIZATION ACTIVITIES, SUCH AS PRELIMINARY ASSESSMENTS AND SITE INSPECTIONS AT POTENTIAL OR CONFIRMED HAZARDOUS WASTE SITES.ACTIVITIES:THIS AGREEMENT SUPPORTS SITE SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES RELATED TO REMEDIAL INVESTIGATIONS, FEASIBILITY STUDIES, PROPOSED PLANS, AND REMEDIAL DESIGNS AT THE ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY'S (EPA) LEAD SITES PURSUANT TO COMPREHENSIVE ENVIRONMENTAL RESPONSE, COMPENSATION, AND LIABILITY ACT (CERCLA). THE STATE WILL PROVIDE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE AND MANAGEMENT ASSISTANCE TO EPA AT NATIONAL PRIORITIES LIST (NPL), NPL CALIBER AND FEDERAL SITES OF INTEREST IN TENNESSEE THROUGHOUT THE REMEDIAL RESPONSE ACTION IN THE FORM OF DOCUMENT REVIEW AND COMMENT.SUBRECIPIENT:NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.OUTCOMES:THE OUTCOME OF THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT WILL IMPROVE THE STATE'S ABILITY TO CONTROL RISKS TO HUMAN HEALTH AND/OR THE ENVIRONMENT AND MAKE THE LAND AVAILABLE FOR REUSE. DELIVERABLES WILL INCLUDE REPORTS FOR PRE-REMEDIAL ACTIVITIES. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROGRAM ARE RESIDENTS OF TENNESSEE.
